Although the face-offs between heroine's father (played by Murali) and hero are quite interesting, the story moves at a slow pace boring the audience to no end.
Southpaw is a lethal concoction of drama and pugilistic action.
Yates fails to give his leading man any depth.
Is the film gritty? No. Is it emotional? No. Is the love story worth the bloodshed? No. Is it worth your money? You know the answer.

It's a riveting portrayal of a fading superhero star who is used as a prop to understand the workings of prestige, power games and how fame's intoxication can soon wear out into futility and redundancy.
The celluloid rendering of RL Stine's Goosebumps is a delightful feat.
Director Wes Ball imbues the right level of energy with inspired, high-octane action pieces keeping you glued.
Here is a passable entertainer that can be the cause of your child's mirth but that's about it.

There is no escaping the fact that No Escape, despite all the bludgeoning, is a guilty pleasure you'll be tempted to take. The loopy script ridden with shameful cliches ends up taking a backseat, as you get on this roller-coaster ride.
She's Funny That Way is a charming little film which benefits from its quaint milieu.
Chan's Dragon Blade is a pleasant surprise, executed with visible grandeur and can claim to be an earnestly performed, crisply edited, smart [film].
The movie has its heartfelt peaks but suffers from inconsistent writing.
Bhatt churns out a quasi-gratifying film, which has all the necessary commercial ingredients -- from romance to good music to thunderous action sequences.
Tugging at the heartstrings, this movie has enough innocence to get you misty-eyed.
Lily James as Cinderella and Richard Madden as the Prince deliver fresh performances with a pleasant chemistry.
One can fault the film for lacking inventiveness, but in terms of its entertainment quotient, it's an enthralling treat for those who have the appetite to digest mass-destruction in movies.
It's an average fare which could've been far better had its meanderings been trimmed.
Big Game is a film which, despite its hackneyed writing, is imbued with charm and humour.
Undeniably, the smarts are visible in its original thinking but it doesn't translate into a satiating viewing experience.
The film has all the makings of a fascinating drama but the half-baked plot turns [out] to be too problematic.
With a solid story in place, this vivaciously shot reincarnation drama is plotted carefully with its loose-ends knotting up into a thrilling end.
What works best here is the film's unpredictability.
Those well-acquainted with world cinema won't find it exceptional. The film's writing is superficial as the story evidently fails to add depth to any of its characters.
Cuteness overload.
Global Baba is subversive but doesn't have an inventive streak. It points out problems without delving deeper or providing a solution. This one is just old wine in an old bottle!
Hero is a delectable synthesis of startling onscreen beauty, dazzling high octane action, melodious music and merry froth.
Even with its glitches, The Conjuring 2 gets one thing right; it scares the hell out of you.
Shraddha and Tiger are earnest and director Sabbir Khan's efforts show, but the focus is not on making a good film. Just winsome action suffices for the makers.
If you at all want to watch this film, go for the original. The dubbed version is no fun.
Laal Rang is half-baked and unconvincing. Despite the grit, it never becomes a riveting film.

With so much going for the film, it isn't so faultless. Technical glitches aside, the story meanders in the second hour. The men are singularly villainified! You will be moved in many scenes but that doesn't culminate into a wholesome viewing experience.
Despite its freshness, the film fails to create an impact. It is hard to be affected by it due to its lack of depth.
For those who survive, a dialogue from the film will resound - 'Sometimes stupid things work'. Well, we daresay, they don't.
You wish the writer-director had used some logic; the film wouldn't have been this silly.

Even though Dhanak stays mysterious till its last scene, it gets too repetitive to hold your interest. Its soulful music, heartfelt style of narration and of course, delightful kids can't make this half-baked story soar.
Dear Dad deserves a watch simply for the profound point it makes about accepting people for who they are and loving them unconditionally.
Skip this one. It will suck the love for horror films out of you.

Chauranga is neither provocative nor skillful in its portrayal. Though its last scene ushers in a ray of hope to nullify the haunting gory glimpses from the film, it never soars high enough to affect you.
Alas, the story is never supported by a solid screenplay. The film's pace is a problem and though things gear up in the second half, it ends as a loopy mess.
It could've been a lot funnier with some better writing.
Love, Rosie is quaint comfort-cinema that makes for an amiable watch.
This dreadfully boring film ends with the hope of a sequel. It's time to introduce the makers to John Lennon. 'Make love, not war...'
Culminating into a horrendously gore-filled climax, this shallow movie offers nothing new and is infuriatingly tiresome to sit through.
It is hard to appreciate a narrative that can only skim the surface but then again Emilia and Sam's chemistry makes you buy into their cozy world.
This is strictly popcorn entertainment which is good while it lasts but offers nothing to take back home.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There is very little heart to all the mad rush in the movie.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With Professor Xavier reminding Magneto that there is good in him, a scene from the luminous First Class flashes, making you wish you were watching that one instead. This is strictly for the fans!
This is a plain biopic that has its heart in the right place but doesn't deliver anything extraordinary.
You wish the film was less conventional in its approach, but it delivers so much that you can barely complain.

It is predictable but that's not such a bad thing when done right. Our hero learns his lesson and manages to 'make his mark'. The same cannot be said about the film that, nevertheless, is a delight to watch.
With an unsurprising climax, weak story and repetitive action, the film fails to be half as good as a regular Statham gag must mandatorily be.
By the end, you won't care who lives or dies, and you'll suspect the filmmakers didn't either.

Regardless of how you may feel about Gore the politician, this film is an important one, and its ultimate message of hope (it's not too late) and duty (as humans, we need to do the right thing by the planet on which we live) is inspiring and invigorating.
Ultimately, it's a work of fiction that, translated to another medium, seems to have lost its punch.
Mehta's film is courageous and reticent, a shout masquerading as a whisper.
If Just My Luck was intended to showcase a more grown-up Lohan (she'll soon be 20), it fails -- but it gives hints of the fine screwball comedian she's already becoming.
The Last Stand, though the weakest in the franchise, is often a kick to watch; you keep wanting more of these characters.
Chen's strength seems to be more with character-driven stories; here's hoping that his next film returns to more comfortable ground.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, we're in the world of elite gymnastics, and Jessica Bendinger's Stick It is an enjoyable exercise in girl power.
... a film that gives you something to think about, raising questions that linger long after the theater lights have brightened.
Keke Palmer, who's been working in television and movies for the past few years, is a natural on screen.
An energetic and often enjoyable documentary, particularly for soccer fans.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... for all its shock value, it is never exploitative, and it has something important to say.
The Break-Up, a grim excuse for a romantic comedy, is basically an hour and 45 minutes spent in the company of two unpleasant people during a miserable time in their lives.
American Dreamz is often a lot of fun, thanks to Weitz's cast.
This is the franchise's third film (each with a different director), and it may well be the most successful of the bunch.
The actors give it a spark, and Grant directs his fine cast with sureness.
Yet another comedy about a man-child who won't grow up, You, Me and Dupree has the faintly stale smell of food left overnight on the counter.
Though the central idea of nostalgia for a quieter, small-town life may well be lost on this movie's young audience -- Cars finds a pleasant and often sparkling groove.

A fairly by-the-numbers route through shootings, framings, diabolical plots and lots of dark-suited Secret Service types talking frantically into their shirt cuffs. (Watch closely, and you'll figure out pretty early who the bad seed is.)
My Super Ex-Girlfriend, simply by having a genuinely funny idea at its core, is one of the summer's better comedies, and director Ivan Reitman and the cast give it a straight-faced silliness.
An enjoyable ride on a dark but not-quite-scary-enough-to-make-you-scream roller coaster, told in elegant motion-capture animation.
An emotional journey, a showcase for two fine actors, and a multifaceted picture of love.
movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Its dreamlike state makes for mesmerizing viewing.
Buried under all this is a rather sweet story about families, but it's hard to see it amongst all the tastelessness.
It meanders agreeably, through some striking buildings and pleasant conversations, and by its end you feel as if you've met somebody.
A goofball riff on the pirate-movie genre, this sequel is as insubstantial as popcorn -- and as delicious.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Superman Returns should swoop away with a big chunk of the summer box office, and deservedly so.
While Stevenson's film unwinds along familiar lines, it delivers unexpected charm.
An exhilarating celebration of a national pastime.
'There is nothing more fun than watching you guys play basketball,' says Resler, at one point, and the great strength of The Heart of the Game is that you can't help but agree.
A pretty soap bubble of a movie. It's lovely to look at and calming to watch, but don't try to touch it - it just might pop and vanish, right there in your hand.
It's a tribute to music's power to heal us, to the way a familiar tune brings a comfortable old-shoe smile and the way a group sing-along bonds those within it, creating a community in that moment.
Single-handedly, Streep lifts Prada from adequate chick flick into intoxicating character study.
In hanging out with Franny, Christine, Jane and Olivia, you get not only a nuanced portrait of women's friendship but a glorious showcase of four actresses in their prime.
Informative (we learn, for example, that exonerees are generally given no follow-up assistance upon release, as parolees are) and deeply moving.
Much of the humor feels tired and unfunny, and David Zucker's directing sags where it should zing.

Like a cup of strong British tea with a sugar cube tossed in, Dan Ireland's Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont is at once sweet and bitter, a fairy-tale friendship in the context of an achingly lonely life.
Failure to Launch is yet another disposable romantic comedy made with little thought or skill.
Hiding among all the uniforms and bullets, it turns out, is an actors' movie, and two actors more than capable of hitting their marks.
Aquamarine isn't good enough to be a teen classic, but its audience will leave the theater happy.
The words Being poor is like being old are scrawled on the door of a shack; like this movie, it's a howl waiting to be heard.
There's a sincerity to the filmmaking here that's at times quite touching: Illusion presents a portrait of true love that's as picture perfect as the sunny spring garden in which we see Isabelle.
As the character grows sicker and quieter, the drama's energy fades.
There is a child at the center of this ultraviolent story, and the devices used to keep us on tenterhooks regarding his survival are appallingly manipulative.
Sometimes it's the most unfilmable novels that make the best movies.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Freedomland, -- is a jittery, overwrought drama that does all it can to vanquish the fine performances lurking within it.
[A] tense but too often preposterous thriller.
A unique, charming coming-of-age film.
It's time to let the Inspector rest in peace.
Jones, directing his first feature, finds the right note in every scene, bringing Arriaga's elegant cipher to life.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Music from the Inside Out is not so much about the people, but about what they create, and it's at its most effective when the talking stops.

[Director] Hood gives the film energy by its unexpected locations, a score both jolting and soaring, and a carefully constructed screenplay that makes everyone in this film a dimensional, complicated character.
As a film, Ask the Dust is uneven; as a labor of love, it's a beauty.
Sophie Scholl: The Final Days doesn't use any cinematic flourishes and embellishments; it doesn't need to.
While it's at times too melodramatic and formulaic to be entirely successful, it still holds some appeal; its very amateurishness is what makes it charming.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: While it may take a few viewings to sort the details out, much about L'Intrus lingers, shimmering quietly in the memory.
Everything about L'Enfant feels devastatingly real.
A predictable and yet thoroughly enjoyable drama about the redemptive power of dance for a group of inner-city teenagers.
Brick is a first feature for Johnson, and while it's not an unqualified success, it definitely marks him as a young filmmaker to watch.

It feels more like a series of bits rather than a coherent narrative, and director Paul McGuigan paces it this way; you never feel as if the entire movie has coalesced, though many of the individual parts are a lot of fun.
Reitman, still in his 20s, knows something that many more seasoned directors never figure out: how to make audiences laugh along with a film that's laughing at itself.
The film feels visually richer than its predecessor, but has the same brand of uncomplicated all-ages charm.
An immensely moving tribute to the power of art.
Despite all the heavy breathing and mood lighting, Basic Instinct 2 is so dull that you might find yourself easily distracted by side issues.
Screening in a new print so pristine you forget that this film is 33 years old, Spirit of the Beehive sweeps you into its quiet world.
movie_title: The Spirit of the Beehive (El Espíritu de la colmena) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Inside Man is a potboiler, but an intriguing one; perhaps Lee should go Hollywood more often.
And so it goes, for a magical 40 minutes: underwater footage often startlingly beautiful, made more so by the immediacy of 3D.
Not much happens in Duck Season, but it's never dull: Eimbcke, a Spanish filmmaker making his feature debut, finds just the right note with his young actors and fills his film with telling detail.
Ultimately it fades away quickly from memory; a sad fate for a good story.
Regardless of how you feel about Johnston's art, The Devil and Daniel Johnston is worth seeing as a poignant portrait of a troubled life, still in the making.
A bouncy comedy/mystery about a young would-be journalist (Scarlett Johansson) trying to solve a crime.
This Flicka may not be a classic, but it's a nice afternoon's entertainment, particularly for girls who ride wild horses in their dreams.
It's a heady, occasionally free-floating mix, and a feast for music lovers.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A quiet gem, suitable for all ages.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It succeeds well at what it sets out to do: wrapping a worthy message in a compelling story.
But F*** gives short shrift to a question that many moviegoers may well ponder: How, exactly, has this word become a substitute for wit, or, in many movies, for dialogue?
The Nativity Story has a quiet sincerity to it that's sometimes quite moving, and sometimes just too quiet.
Ultimately rises above its inadequacies; it's an earnest tribute to a time gone by, and to a symbol of hope.
The result is intoxicating; a free-spinning story that's by its end enormously satisfying, creating its own kind of magic.
It succeeds well at what it sets out to do: wrapping a worthy message in a compelling story.
The movie's saved by an appealing star, a swift pace and a vivid setting.
Arbus (whose actual work is unseen, presumably because of rights issues) remains an enigma, and Kidman's wispy portrayal doesn't give the film the center it needs.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful and enjoyable documentary from Barbara Kopple.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... a quiet but often giggly pleasure.
Those astonished to learn that animals are slaughtered to make hamburgers may well find Richard Linklater's clumsy Fast Food Nation educational; the rest of us may be underwhelmed.
Always an intelligent presence on screen, Harris here embraces the challenge of showing us the man behind the wall of music.

Watching Amy Berg's powerful documentary Deliver Us from Evil is a wrenching experience; her subjects reveal to the camera almost unbearable levels of anguish, and its audience walks away feeling both numbness and rage.
It's refreshing to be in the hands of a filmmaker with a unique vision, and a pleasure to be challenged by a film's flights of imagination.
Technically accomplished but fairly lifeless and at times a bit silly.
Ultimately, the real Chris Gardner emerges as an inspirational American success story -- and Will Smith emerges as a fine and nuanced actor.
The film, directed by Gary Winick (13 Going on 30) has a sweetness of its own.
For a film that's ultimately about speed, it could use a little more zip.
Alpha Dog, a tale of a group of drug-fueled teenagers, is gritty to the point of painful abrasion.
Crowe's capable of much better than this; let's hope he gets back on track with the next one.
Notes on a Scandal emerges as a remarkable character study: difficult to watch, impossible to look away.

Tykwer, best known for the ultramodern chase movie Run Lola Run, would seem an unusual choice for a period film, but he infuses the sometimes stately story with vigor; though well past two and a half hours, it never feels long.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's a soft-focus picture of a woman who, surely, had a few more hard edges, but it's a thoroughly pleasant escape to another world.
It's a truly inspiring story; pity the movie doesn't live up to it.

A thoughtful and beautifully mounted story for grown-ups, The Painted Veil brings the quiet pleasures of a fine novel, showing us that the world's complicated geography is no match for the terrain of the human heart.
Dreamgirls wraps you up in its music, like a velvet coat of sound, and when it's over you feel warmed, happy and thoroughly entertained.
Interesting to watch, up to a point. The Good German gets lost amidst its references; it doesn't stand by itself but is held up by the films that inspired it.
It's a long (nearly three hours), deliberately paced film, and an intelligent one.
Amidst all of this excess, an actor can too easily disappear, or be reduced to a hanger for a costume. But Gong Li, the standout in the cast, does wonders with her melodramatic role.
The movie, despite some lavish special effects, feels perfunctory and generic. Kids may well enjoy it (the 7-year-old with me giggled all the way through); adults may squirm.
Ultimately, is Rocky Balboa necessary? Of course not. But neither are plenty of other movies that find their way to theaters, and this one at least provides some undemanding entertainment.
...It's a rare pleasure to see a film that assumes literacy on the part of its audience.
On a rainy day, A Good Year may be welcome fantasy; the question is whether anyone will remember it after the clouds have parted.
The Ant Bully isn't a kid classic, but it's an enjoyable diversion until the next ant movie comes along.
Stranger Than Fiction is both about a novel and like a novel; you eagerly await the turning of the pages.
The cheerfully tasteless Borat is often screamingly funny and almost never dull, and that's more than I can say for just about every comedy to grace screens this year.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's some genuine heart here, particularly in Sam and Matt's subplot.
All the King's Men is full of bits that work; unfortunately, they never quite add up to a whole.
One of the more positive things I can say about JNT is that it serves the function of a crash diet: After seeing it, you will not want to eat again for a very, very long time.
... The Last Kiss takes a serious look at what's too often described glibly as early midlife crisis, and it shows some courage in not tying up its stories neatly at the end.
It's a haunting and welcome addition to the growing library of war documentaries; one that wisely lets its subjects speak for themselves.
... despite plenty of bumps, this road comedy gets to its destination just fine.
All of this sometimes feels just a bit self-indulgent, and more than a bit random -- but then again, isn't that exactly what dreams can be?
It can be tricky to watch both screens at once (Conversations With Other Women rewards multiple viewings), but it's invigorating to see a filmmaker exploring technique as metaphor.
Co-writer/directors Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland have crafted a small gem, one of those movies from which you emerge feeling happier about the human condition.
George Bamber's film is bouncy and agreeable but has a certain flatness to it; never making the case for its existence as a movie rather than a comic strip.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Dominik Moll's masterfully cast psychological thriller Lemming crackles with tension; its story keeps going off to unexpected places as we watch breathlessly, unable to look away.
File The Night Listener under Missed Opportunities.
Co-directors Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris have pulled off the essential ingredient for this kind of film: a cast that believably creates a family.
There's something about Fiscuteanu's quietly desperate performance (with much of the emotion conveyed through his eyes), that gets under your skin.
While Burger's screenplay isn't always graceful, the movie's lovely enough that you might not notice.
Persuasively argues that the board is ineffective and crippled by conflicts of interest.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though Lennon's commitment to a peaceful world is vivid and unquestionable, The U.S. vs. John Lennon ultimately emerges as a picture of a different kind of commitment: a love story.
Those fond of films set in quaint, remote British towns (this one's named Little Wallup), or really any film in which the divine Smith purses her lips, will find much to enjoy here.
Death of a President is thought-provoking, but as much for 'how'd they do that?' as for its ideas.
Running with Scissors looks great, and works fine when Bening is on screen; otherwise, it's off-balance, teetering where it should hold steady.
A rather sweet, wistful little movie that just happens to have a lot of explicit sex in it.
An assured bonbon of a film that's thoroughly and deliciously entertaining.

Once this World War II drama finds its footing -- and much of the film goes by before it does - it's extremely moving. At the end, a flag dances quietly in a whispering breeze, celebrating the film's real-life heroes as eloquently as any words.
Little happens for much of Marie Antoinette, but Coppola is a visual storyteller, and with her first big canvas she creates a giddy world at Versailles in color and light.
I'll wait breathlessly for 56 Up, and hope this brave group will speak to the camera again; giving us the gift of a share in their lives.
Barry Levinson's Man of the Year squanders a promising premise; it's ultimately overlong, underwritten and strangely unfunny.
A pointless junior version of James Bond minus the budget (and the suaveness).
Infamous is quietly stolen by Sandra Bullock as Harper Lee.
An empty experience; lots of shadow and noise, adding up to very little.
Macdonald has delivered a masterful tragedy, told in his characters' wary eyes.
That Scorsese can hit this kind of material out of the park isn't surprising, and much of The Departed gleams with a certain well-honed perfection.
Employee of the Month, which finds its comedic apex in watching cashiers scanning purchases, is disposable filmmaking, with its shelf life already up.
Gela Babluani, according to the film's sparse press kit, is only 26 years old but already knows more about suspense than some filmmakers learn in a career.
It's a quiet and poignant look at a life as it slips away, seen through the eyes of a character who's not always likable but remains entirely real.
The characters never really emerge as individuals; they're pretty puppets, moving through their prescribed paces.
Ultimately, this workplace fairy tale creates its own cheer. When its time is up, you'll feel like you've been in good company.
Though it never really builds to a point, the film presents an intriguing form of storytelling, giving us glimpses of these people's lives and personalities.
movie_title: The 10th District Court: Moments of Trial (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Remember these names; remember this strange, lovely movie.
A superhero saga grounded in the real world.

Essentially, Mr. & Mrs. Smith exists for the purpose of showing off the gorgeous faces and physiques of its two stars, and for giving its audience the dubious pleasure of watching them beat each other up.
For wine-loving filmgoers willing to lavish it, and to forgive the film its excesses, it offers refreshment and reward.
Pardon its dust, and you'll be rewarded with a moving story of a time gone by, and of an unexpected hero.
A sweet-natured journey not to a galaxy far, far away, but to someplace just as mysterious: the first tentative steps toward adulthood, taken here by four teenage girls.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Leitman gives us a comprehensive array of pinup photos, news clips and wrestling footage from these women's younger years, and gives the women plenty of camera time to emerge as individuals and personalities.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film's a diverting enough 105 minutes, with a few surprises in store.
It's indifferent, charisma-free filmmaking.
Monster-in-Law is a comedy without laughs and a catfight without claws.
A brilliant, sprawling piece of cinematic art, and perhaps the best film of the year.
movie_title: The Best of Youth (La meglio gioventù) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It just plods along, harmless but lifeless, going exactly where you think it's going.
Crash, Paul Haggis' flawed but riveting tale of racism in contemporary Los Angeles, has moments so powerful they're instantly seared into your memory; you'll watch without blinking, barely breathing.
It's just shock for shock's sake. It doesn't linger in the imagination the way, say, David Lynch's shocking content often does; rather, you just want it to go away.
Dance has had the great good fortune to cast two legendary British actresses, and thus Ladies in Lavender gets elevated to the rare-treat category.
A bland piece of work, more so than the original.
Ephron seems unsure as to whether she's filming a zany retro comedy or a conventional romance, and the film zips back and forth between genres, never really settling.

Bier, honored as an Emerging Master at the Seattle International Film Festival this year, is clearly a director to watch. In her hands, a story that could become melodramatic is gripping and heartbreaking.
If you missed The Bad News Bears the first time around, this one might be worth catching just for Thornton; otherwise, it's just extra innings on a game that's already played out.
The story, told with little dialogue or action, feels like an outline awaiting shading and detail.
Ozon, as he's shown in his many recent films (particularly Under the Sand), knows a thing or two about love and loss; 5x2 achingly demonstrates both.
Every now and then, Brewer pulls off a near-miracle with his flinty characters: He lets us, for a moment, slip into their lives -- and sing their song.
The verse quickly lifts the movie into a celebration of language, both spoken and unspoken.
The storytelling is problematic -- Binh seems uncannily able to find the right people at the right time -- and the performances uneven.
There's no reason why this movie shouldn't have worked: it's got a funny premise, a talented cast and an obviously lavish budget. But it lands without even a crash; just a dull, unfunny thud.
An intricate ensemble comedy about sex, lies and reproduction, has some messy spots, but overall it's a warm, quirky story about people who seem spiky and real.
Burton has pulled off the near-impossible: a fresh look at a classic.
A vivid picture of a relationship that, like most, isn't quite picture-perfect.

LaChapelle's powerful street-dance documentary Rize never lets us forget that its subjects are dancing in a war zone. But dance they do, in a kind of controlled frenzy, with music throbbing and limbs whirling and swaying and pulsing to the beat.
The plot's standard-issue, owing much to zombie movies that have staggered before this one.
A mostly faithful adaptation of a scary little story: A mother and her young daughter, needing to save money as the mother negotiates an unhappy divorce, move into a depressing, dark apartment.
July's oddball vision grows on you, and I found myself looking forward to her next film.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A sumptuous but occasionally soporific nature documentary.
His film, both reverent and affectionate, has at its heart a story that richly deserves the telling.
Ultimately, the film is an affectionately manly tribute to these athletes, for whom every game -- and every day -- is a triumph.
Gibney's documentary is ultimately not about business and numbers but about morality; how a group of people, blinded by money, lost their souls.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A Lot Like Love ... is a cute movie.
Ultimately, this is one man's story, told with great empathy, and Amenábar deserves great credit for lifting the film above the soap-opera sentimentality into which it could have easily fallen.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Like a bridal shower, it's probably more fun if you have some champagne first. Perhaps some enterprising theater manager will consider this.
Sentimental but occasionally moving drama.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A meticulous and often fascinating reconstruction of a chaotic time.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: We smile and maybe even weep on cue, but we're still kept at a distance looking in, peering through a pretty window.
The last weekend of January is traditionally a dumping ground for turkeys at the multiplexes, so don't say you weren't warned.
Faint praise it may be, but those looking for a cute date movie this weekend could do far worse. As could Smith, for that matter.
While it's got a refreshingly dry, nasty tone, the film is never quite as funny as it needs to be.
For those willing to ponder, this is a worthy feast of words and images.
The movie is at times startling in its impact.
Fans should appreciate the remake for what it is: a breathless little revisit to that old precinct house, expertly performed.

Filled with pretty faces and empty logic, David Moreton's noir-wannabe Testosterone flounders about, doing everything but flutter its eyelashes in an attempt to distract us from its lack of substance.

The dark violence of the film (parents, note: Pan's Labyrinth is not for children) is leavened by its invention -- by the way it pushes the limits of reality and fantasy, each world overlapping with the other.
Kassell, a first-time feature filmmaker, shows confidence and some lovely instincts.
Beauty and ugliness mingle in this play, with the beauty of language ultimately triumphing.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Eager to tell one story, Inside Deep Throat neglects the more compelling story within it.
Watch it as a movie musical and you may be disappointed; watch it as an experiment in genres and be intrigued; watch it for the birth of an international star and be dazzled.
Opens a window to a culture we rarely see, creating both a small story of a mother and daughter and a vast story of female empowerment.
Ticks along like a freshly wound-up clock, smart and precise, keeping its audience just breathless enough not to notice that more than two hours have passed.
Jaoui, crisply efficient as Sylvia, reveals herself as a talent to watch, and Berry disappears into the role of Lolita, carrying the movie on her weary shoulders.
A story of wounded children, a devastating reminder of the costs of war.
Turns out to be that rarity: a movie that makes its audience happier for having seen it.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In theory, this should all be scary, but it just isn't. You giggle at the B-movie cheesiness of it.
Nusuppaev simply isn't skilled enough to bring us along on Schizo's journey, and Omarova's sense of pace is uneven.
The screenplay, by Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel, struggles to make up for a fundamental lack of suspense.
Watching this film is like spending an evening with a prickly, opinionated, thoughtful cineaste friend -- one who has a vast stock of DVDs at the ready.
A gentle illustration of that particular moment in childhood when the world begins to make its mark.
A wrenchingly sweet and beautifully acted film that keeps surprising us -- it never takes us where we think it's going, but always where we want to go.
Profoundly sad, but it's made with such artistry that it's almost uplifting; you watch it mesmerized, immersed in the strange community the children create.

Maybury tricks everything up with a hyperkinetic directing style that relies heavily on constant flashes, trippy quick cuts, icily bleached-out colors and frequent, odd close-ups of everyone's dental work.
Haunting.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Keeps wandering off on tangents, and after a while its audience does, too.
Enlivened by some good performances, but it's ultimately overfamiliar and slow, and its characters feel like they were dreamed up by a screenwriter -- no one ever seems to breathe real air.
Purists may miss their favorite bits or raise eyebrows over the somewhat altered ending, but the book's goofball -- and very British -- humor survives intact.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A Good Woman suffers from a staggeringly bad miscasting of its central role and from a cut-and-paste screenplay that substitutes random insertions of Wilde epigrams for character.
As fantasies go, you could do a lot worse.
Rob Cohen's airborne adventure Stealth commits the cardinal sin for an action movie: It's very, very dull.
Jackson spoils us with riches in this film, with one impossible sequence after another; the result is overwhelming but pleasantly so.
Not quite laugh-out-loud funny, but pleasant.
Watch closely and listen carefully during Syriana because Stephen Gaghan's movie is that rarity: a thinking person's drama.
Grown-up children who remember our own travels in Narnia will find that many of the details resonate beautifully.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Jesus Is Magic may be a bit too much for anyone but the most hardcore Silverman fan.
Bland and witless.
Some will find it touching, some will be too weary of the plot contrivances and the smug Stone family to care.
Most of the musical numbers aren't stylized (a natty tango number is an exception) but based in a Hollywood-gritty reality that at times feels silly.

Dance fans will be dazzled by its treasure trove of archival dance footage. But those who know little of ballet will find plenty here to feed the soul, in the film's rich portraits of men and women nearing the end of a life lived in the arts.
Though the special effects in this film are often breathtaking, the real drama is here is exactly where it should be: in a young man's frightened but resolute eyes.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Dying Gaul is often wicked fun.
Too often it has the uncomfortable feel of a too-small sweater - - stretched to capacity, still not covering the territory.
Pride & Prejudice satisfies as dreamy romance. It's not the razor-sharp satire that Austen can be, but it's lovely entertainment.
It has the messiness of real life, with uncombed hair and unanswered questions.
Walk the Line is less music history than love story, and it comes down to the performances of the two people at its center, both of which are splendid.
It stays with you after you've seen it, like a haunting strain of music; both love song and elegy for what might have been.
Would somebody, please, find the right comic vehicle for Téa Leoni?
It's a smart, mesmerizing and often angry film, from a truly confident filmmaker, but it remains, maddeningly, just beyond our grasp.
Naughty (and nice) children of all ages, particularly little girls, should gobble this one up, and rightly so.
The result is haunting and often creepy in its realism.
The New World laps over its audience like water on a deserted beach, moving so quietly that you almost don't notice that it's enveloped you.
Match Point isn't one of his truly great films, like Annie Hall or Manhattan, but it's a very good one; a sign that a career that seemed stalled is purring along once more.

Huffman's performance in Transamerica, as a pre-op male-to-female transsexual coping with the sudden emergence of a long-lost son, is much better than the movie it's in; indeed, she singlehandedly takes Transamerica to a higher plane.
A fascinating portrait of an American family in 1969 (much of the short film 'Sean' is included) and today, strained by different value systems and yet still bound by love.
The redoubtable Mrs. Henderson is the sort of character that Dench was born to play: funny, eccentric, cranky and with a spine of all-too-visible steel.
The White Countess is never less than lovely to look at, and sometimes much more.

The digital animation ranges from competent to clunky, the jokes too often feel tossed-off and random, and the movie too often descends into dullness, only to be yanked back from the abyss by the goat.
OK, so you really don't need me to tell you about Glory Road if you've ever seen a sports movie before. Just get out your sports-movie-cliché checklist and a pencil.

While Tristan & Isolde, a competent but uninspired film version of the legendary medieval romance, will likely fade from theaters and memories quickly, Myles' lovely face and spirited performance should linger.
Unevenly paced yet darkly funny and consistently intriguing.
... an unabashedly old-fashioned musical filled with song, dance, and shtick so shticky you could hang wallpaper with it.
Ultimately, Memoirs of a Geisha compares unfavorably with the book, though it offers pleasures of its own.
A funny idea, alas, doesn't necessarily make for a funny movie.
Jarhead is often a film about boredom, but it's never boring; full of unexpected touches and detailed character turns.
Though beautifully photographed, there's something creepy at the heart of Lila Says.
It's an odd up-and-down storyline, and it's told with too many shortcuts: pop songs used in place of dialogue and emotion, pop references used in place of jokes.
An oddly dreary love story, seemingly taking place in slow-motion.
2046 isn't entirely successful: It's very high-concept and can be difficult to follow. But when it was over, I immediately wanted to watch it again.
There's a looseness to the camera work and storytelling that's appealingly breezy: This film feels, for better or worse, like real life.
It's contrived, cutesy and quickly tiresome.
The 40-Year-Old Virgin disarms us -- it is, at its heart, a sweet-natured romantic comedy. Unfortunately, you have to clear away a fair bit of debris to find that heart.
Dick's film puts a human face on a churchwide scandal that sometimes seems too big to comprehend.
This film, like the actress who inspired it, has an appealing sweetness that sneaks up on its viewer.
Smart, well-crafted and satisfying.
A competent exercise in atmospheric bosom-heaving, if not plausible storytelling.
Becomes a quiet tribute to friendship, and to the way that something torn can be made perfect again.
Most of us really, really don't want to be a fly on the wall while somebody else's family works out its issues in interstate therapy sessions.
Grizzly Man is the strange, sad and mesmerizing tale of a man who wanted to be a bear.
It's very funny, but it's also a bit dull.
There's lots of bad stuff brewing on the bayou in this occasionally scary but more often silly movie, which wastes some good actors along the way.
Jarmusch shows us, as he has in the past, that the journey, not the arrival, matters.
Though it's made with wit, style and sweetness, it may be a tricky match for American audiences.

Wood's fine work is undermined by the movie it's trapped in, which feels like a rough draft of itself: Skander Halim's screenplay is unnecessarily twisty and gimmicky, and some of the teenspeak dialogue falls flat, already out of date.
As courtroom drama, The Exorcism of Emily Rose works effectively; as a scarefest, it misses the mark. But the performances stick with you, particularly that of Linney, who has an elegant steeliness.
What makes Corpse Bride sing, ultimately, is the breadth of imagination that it demonstrates; creating a cluttered, textured and mysteriously beautiful world that we're loathe to leave at the end.
As delicately and precisely constructed as a spider's web, Nine Lives is a quiet triumph.
Streep, beaming in her horn-rimmed glasses and spouting platitudes like 'Focus on the now, for now,' makes it all a treat.
It's all believable enough, but it never sings.

The great strength of Miller's film -- aside from Hoffman's brilliant portrayal -- is that it both tells the story behind Capote's masterpiece, the true-crime tale In Cold Blood, and serves as an homage to it.
She's [Caro] got a good story to tell (based, loosely, on a real-life case), and a marvelous cast to help her tell it.
Stay is crowded with layers and symbols, probably too many for one movie, and it ultimately wears out its welcome. But its images are compelling, even as its story fades away.
An uneven but loving tribute to a remarkable woman -- who would, undoubtedly, have wished to rewrite it herself.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: See it, to see what the news once was -- and to see what movies can be.
You might call it a musical without songs (mostly), or a farce without enough doors to slam, or a comedy without enough jokes.
This movie is a treat; take the kids and have a grand day out.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In Her Shoes is aimed squarely at a demographic -- grown-up women -- who aren't often catered to by Hollywood, and it's competent and sometimes charming. But there's a soap-opera blandness to it that even the gifted cast can't overcome.
A sweet-natured, prettily photographed and at times genuinely exciting drama, bogged down by some thinly written characters and syrupy music.
Mills, working from a novel by Walter Kirn, brings some unusual touches to a film that could easily have become a standard indie coming-of-age tale.
Despite the blood, the film follows Cronenberg's marvelous Spider in finding its true horror in the dark corners of the mind.
Just another thriller with too much plot.
The film's twisty structure -- mirroring that of the book -- eventually grows tiresome without a strong central character to anchor it.

In washed-out tones of brown and khaki, mimicking the colors of the troops' uniforms (blood, used sparingly, is startlingly crimson, seeming to sear a hole in the screen), the film plays out in a mood of resignation and control.

This is a vast subject, ideally suited to a series of films. It's at its most moving when focusing on the small stories of individual artworks taken from their owners and restored to the families decades later.

The film's plot, revolving around a murder investigation that turns nasty, ticks along smoothly and efficiently. But it's ultimately more of a character drama, and a reminder that great acting often has little to do with words.

See this one on the biggest screen you can (IMAX, ideally), and experience both the magic of top-notch technical filmmaking and the bittersweet pleasure of watching a young actor, gone too soon, giving a performance that won't be forgotten.
The sky is relentlessly blue, the sun bright even in the thick of night. In this odd and unforgettable place, Herzog has made his own poetry.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tell No One is an intricate puzzle for a summer evening; a thriller with a rare touch of bittersweet romance.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Its story is a familiar one, whatever the decade.
This is a sweet, G-rated story of 1930s girl power, with nary a princess in sight.

The final third seems all shot in a strange blue light that makes even the gorgeous Theron look consumptive, and is, in a nutshell, no fun at all. Aren't Fourth of July movies supposed to be fun? No fireworks this time, Will.
None of this would matter much if this movie wasn't anchored by a star turn, and Streep delivers yet another in a career full of them.
Fugitive Pieces is an often lovely work, haunting its viewer long afterward with its quiet observations on what remains with us.

Though the film looks elegant, with deceptively simple interiors creating an impression of great wealth, it feels remote. We're impressed by the work the actors are doing, yet the characters don't hold our interest.
At least it doesn't waste any time. At somewhere near the 30-second mark, it gets right down to business, and that business is the kind of humor that doesn't usually get named in this paper.
The screenplay is a mess, filled with unfunny moments of intended humor and funny moments of unintended humor.

To criticize a film called The Tracey Fragments for being too fragmented may sound a bit on-the-nose, but this experimental drama from Canadian director Bruce McDonald is interesting for a while and then goes to pieces.
This is one of those movie ideas that leaves you wondering what other ideas, exactly, were rejected in favor of this one, on the grounds of being too lame.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a complex and conflicted look at a family, torn apart by rifts and yet still bonded by love.

This is Pixar's most audacious film yet, and some small children may become impatient with the film's long wordless stretches. But the storytelling is so meticulous and skilled, some may not even notice the absence of dialogue.
Hicks structures Glass in 12 vignettes, each highlighting a different aspect of Glass' life, and some are more compelling than others.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a movie, it doesn't add up to much; as another glimpse at two characters who remain fascinating, it's worth seeing.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Brideshead Revisited, it turns out, deserves a revisit.
Eric Guirado's lovely French drama The Grocer's Son is about that moment in a young person's life when he realizes that he is, despite all efforts to the contrary, a grown-up.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This emotionally wrenching drama is an actors' showcase, a primer on quick-and-dirty filmmaking that nonetheless looks beautiful, and a welcome-to-the-big-leagues party for Anne Hathaway.
Harris displays a quiet, unshowy confidence and a genuine fondness for the genre, capturing the horses and guns and saloon glasses in a soft, almost-sundown light.
Fernando Meirelles' Blindness is film as punishment; a literate and thoughtful work that's nonetheless so relentless in its bleached-out misery that you want to look away.
Fiennes, an actor who disappears into roles like ice in a teacup, makes the Duke a complex and almost sympathetic figure, a bulky, unappealing man whose interests are in all the wrong things.
The chase eventually wears thin, and Eagle Eye eventually strangles its actors in the threads of its plot.
Hamlet 2 is a likable movie even as it careens around like a wagging tail, but it's just too uneven.
Tropic Thunder is too much promise and not enough delivery.
Man on Wire should be watched on the biggest screen possible; it's an utterly thrilling exploration of one man's mad dream.
America the Beautiful provides plenty of food for thought, and Roberts' passion for the subject shines through.
A likable movie that ultimately confirms the importance of women's friendship.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an age difference of 30 years, their connection was immediately electric; their first kiss, the story goes, broke a window.
Swing Vote, an oddly off-balance comedy directed by Joshua Michael Stern, feels like two movies; one much better than the other.

Roman Polanski (The Pianist, Rosemary's Baby, Chinatown) is unquestionably a great filmmaker, but as Marina Zenovich's documentary Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired perhaps unintentionally demonstrates, he's also a creep.
Brideshead Revisited, it turns out, deserves a revisit.
Sex and the City: The Movie is no great shakes as a movie, but it doesn't have to be. What it does have to be is a happy revisit to a land its fans know well, and on that level it works very well.
Ultimately W. feels flat, despite the good work of the cast.
It's as if Burton was born to direct it.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A brief, haunting tale of three women in contemporary Tel Aviv, Jellyfish seems to float in its viewers' consciousness; you'll remember its images long afterward.
A sweet-natured family adventure film that should be quite popular with the grade-school girls at which it's aimed.
Leatherheads is no disaster, but it leaves you wanting both less and more.
Those of us who'll happily watch Caine in pretty much anything will find enough pleasures here.
21 doesn't quite hit the jackpot, but with popcorn it should satisfy.
Though it's no Boys Don't Cry, there's something about Stop-Loss that haunts you: Peirce has an uncanny way of catching the fierce light in her actors' eyes.
One of the most beautiful films ever made.
It takes tremendous courage to expose one's life to the camera as Fox does here, and while she answers few of the universal (to women, anyway) questions she raises, at least she's asking them.
movie_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Sachs has assembled a stellar ensemble cast, and much of the pleasure of Married Life is watching the subtle detail the actors bring to their roles.
Maybe I should have bought popcorn; this movie undoubtedly goes down better when it's partially drowned out by munching.
Girls Rock! happily pulls off the trick of being both entertaining and moving; grown-up girls may well watch with an occasional tear as we see the campers subtly transform.
A lively and often enchanting '30s screwball that just happens to be brand-new.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Kolirin wonderfully maintains an atmosphere of both humor and melancholy.
Important viewing for anyone contemplating a birth plan.
Sweet as gingerbread, Penelope deserves to find an audience; those with a taste for happily-ever-afters should look for it, before it too-quickly disappears.
Working with utterly predictable material, screenwriter Kevin Hench finds plenty of offbeat humor, and Carolla knows how to make it sing.
Delightful.
Monster Camp introduces us to several of its cheerful practitioners, letting what first seems odd slowly make sense to the uninitiated.
movie_title: Monster Camp: The Story of NERO Seattle (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Nobody does steely quite like the basso-voiced Page -- her Vanessa is a sort of Young Republican version of Juno.
Milner and Poulter are a lot of fun to watch, a pair of first-timer naturals who don't reek of Dakota Fanning Young Actorliness.
The actors seem lost in a gumball dispenser; the audience, for the most part, might well feel the same way.
We all know what happens in Vegas -- and we know, without having to watch it, what happens in this movie.
Love Songs finds the magic that the great screen musicals have -- the way a sad song can nonetheless leave an audience happy, or the way two voices blending seems to create something so much bigger.
Overall Then She Found Me, though earnest and clearly heartfelt, just feels tired; like Hunt's sad-eyed April, it lacks spark.
A movie that's often enjoyable but never as good as the ones it's stealing from.
Everyone, including Madrid, looks terrific, but Deception delivers on no other level, except perhaps as a guide to various New York hotel rooms.
Baby Mama ultimately gives in to sweetness, but it has some deliciously tart moments along the way.
Wong Kar Wai's strange pastry-filled reverie My Blueberry Nights is not for those who like movies in which things happen; rather, it's for those in a mood to float, sometimes deliciously.
Pierre Salvadori's delightful comedy, picturesquely set in a series of posh hotels on the French Riviera, throws together two terrific comic actors and an irresistible premise.

This gifted writer/director knows how to illuminate those moments in which people realize they have become essential to each other -- that each person's life has been gently changed by the other's presence.
It's an emotional tapestry, sure to both delight audiences and move them to tears.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall should please audiences eager for silly summer comedy (particularly, the Hawaiian sunshine should delight those currently enduring a gray Seattle spring).
The only enjoyable elements to this film are Pacino's impressively hardworking hair (no matter how bad Jack Gramm's day gets, his exuberant hair looks fabulous).
It's swift and watchable enough, and the actors keep things interesting, but ultimately the movie falls short.
An ingenuous knot of plot, expertly tangled, in which nothing is quite what it seems.
The Other Boleyn Girl is an agreeable piece of filmmaking, carefully and sometimes artfully balancing solemnity with fluff.
Okonedo is at times heartbreakingly good as May, who carries a deep well of pain inside her; Keys is nicely fiery as June, who takes time to warm up to the visitors.
Overall, this is a lovely film, ranking with the best of Disney's animated features while taking on rather serious issues of war, honor, gender roles and family pride.
The Edge of Love is the sort of muddled melodrama that has little to say about love, or anything else.
Directed by Christine Jeffs, Sunshine Cleaning has more than its share of indie clichés, but it's wonderfully cast and often a pleasure to watch.
Watching Duplicity brings pleasures all too rare: gorgeous actors speaking smart, funny dialogue in beautiful settings.
The Betrayal (Nerakhoon) is a remarkable achievement, haunting the viewer long after it ends.
Everlasting Moments unfolds over the decades, showing us a life not entirely transformed by photography but profoundly touched by it.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Given enough popcorn, kids should find it diverting; adults may be less than enthralled.
Do see this movie in 3-D if you can, and don't hesitate to send the kids; there's just enough silly humor to keep them happy.
A quiet, moving tale of love and loss.
Watchman plays as if the filmmakers were afraid to make their own mark. It's a transliteration rather than a translation from one medium to another; a too-often lifeless homage.
The remarkable intimacy Gray finds with his cast lifts the movie up as its quiet story unfolds, pulling us in and making the world smaller until nothing matters but these three.
Such a brief glimpse into these women's lives and art whets the appetite for more; alas, Ballerina ends far too quickly, leaving only their willowy shadows behind.
Everything about it is good-looking, tautly paced and sophisticated; what it isn't, unfortunately, is memorable.
Overall Shopaholic seems to be standing in an empty station, waving a futile hand at a train long gone.
The film is brief and not especially creative in its storytelling, but nonetheless unforgettable; this remarkable story deserved to be captured on film.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay is unusual in its reliance on children for many of the scenes, and its understanding of the drama in the heart of a troubled 9-year-old.
Though James is a passive hero, Eisenberg plays him with such earnest charm that you root for him.
Hannah Montana: The Movie is an excuse for some generically catchy songs and a showcase for Miley Cyrus' charmingly chipmunk-cheeked smile; and on that level, it works well enough.
Absurdistan has more than a little bit of magic at its heart; it's a tale of love and perseverance, gently winking at its happy viewers.
Elegantly shot...and nicely paced, A Wink and a Smile is most appealing in its depiction of the growing camaraderie of the students.
As always, Dick brings passion and immediacy to what's essentially a series of talking heads; his position on the issue is clear and powerfully argued.
Better to seek out these artists' works firsthand than to settle for this tame rehash, pretty as it may be.
Angels & Demons slips away pretty quickly after you've watched it, in the way of most blockbuster movies, but it's diverting enough while it lasts.
[A] frothily entertaining documentary.
It will frustrate many viewers, and it often frustrated me, but there's something about it that keeps your gaze, despite the self-indulgence of much of the filmmaking.
Ghosts of Girlfriends Past doesn't do Dickens any favors, but in a year that brought us Bride Wars, it'll do.
In such a quiet film, the power comes from the details.
Perhaps this was the wrong X-Man to command an entire movie. Somebody find Jackman a role in which he gets to smile, and wake me up when Ian McKellen's back to terrorizing the X-world.
Ellis' book, though a grim read, had a satirical edge to it that made it darkly enjoyable; the movie is simply dark and dull. And vampireless, more's the pity.
A sports movie that transcends its genre.
Tough-minded yet often touching, The Soloist works precisely because it doesn't go where we think it's going to go.

Paris 36 is perhaps overlong for what it is, and it's certainly feather-light, but it gives its watcher an uncomplicated pleasure; like looking through a faded scrapbook, filled with memories once bright.

There's just something utterly winning about the way the guys of Anvil hang on to their dream -- and when, in the movie's final scenes, they find it for a moment, it creates some genuine, headbanging joy.
A busy thriller that moves between the worlds of newspapers and politics, Kevin Macdonald's State of Play zips along smoothly.
Is this what we want in our romantic comedies? Is it too much to hope for smart, dimensional female characters who have more to them than marriage lust (see also -- or rather, don't -- Bride Wars)?
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that's perfectly good, and yet not good enough.
Children who like being scared will get a kick out of this wildly creative movie; adults needn't have a child in tow to enjoy it, too.
The Uninvited goes through its motions efficiently, if soullessly.
Any of these musicians deserves a Walk the Line or Coal Miner's Daughter-type biopic of their own; perhaps this flawed but enjoyable movie is the first step toward that.

Van Sant's film (and why did it take 24 years after the documentary to make this stirring, heartbreaking story a feature film?) finally gives Milk his due -- and becomes an immediate classic of gay cinema.
Baz Luhrmann's entertaining Australia simply must be watched on the biggest screen possible, as I imagine it becomes sillier and sillier as it shrinks.
'When in doubt, bring on the projectile baby vomit' appears to be the guiding comedic principle behind Four Christmases.
An intoxicating mix of genres: comedy, drama, suspense, even Bollywood-style musical.
Days and Clouds, despite its darkness, warmly reminds us that if we have each other, sometimes that's all we need.
Nobel Son isn't funny enough for black comedy, nor suspenseful enough for a thriller; for all its flashy flailings and thumb-slicings, it's ultimately a little dull.

Twilight is often a lot of fun to watch -- the atmosphere of wet green trees and subtle danger, the gothic breathiness of doomed romance, the way all the vampires have better hair than anyone else -- and seems to give its intended audience what it wants.
Synecdoche, New York builds a wall of high concept, so high you can't find the good movie hiding somewhere behind it.
It's not the best comedy of the season, but it's far from the worst, and some days that's more than enough.

Happy-Go-Lucky doesn't provide many insights (even Poppy seems ultimately unsure about whether happiness can be a permanent condition), but it does provide a little joy -- and that's worth celebrating, at the movies and elsewhere.
The line between drama and melodrama is a fine one, and Clint Eastwood steps on both sides of it in his elegantly sad new film, Changeling.

Tornatore, best known for Cinema Paradiso, has meticulously crafted a story that's at times so raw it hurts to watch. Its action blends piercingly lit flashbacks and dream sequences with a gray, prosaic present in an unnamed Italian city.
Everything works out! Everyone's hair looks great! Some of the kids end up at Juilliard! I hope real high school is like this.
This very unsubtle movie's heart is in the right place; its art, unfortunately, isn't.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Howard gives it all an appealing, speedy pace, but most important he gives his two lead actors room to create their complicated, showy characters.
Familiarity is part of the pleasure of holiday movies, and Nothing Like the Holidays gets by not on originality, but on chemistry and warmhearted charm.
Davi, who has the kind of handsomely weathered face that has spent a lot of time gazing into the sun, clearly poured his heart into this movie, and it shows.
There's nothing fresh here; it's a Bridget-Jones-meets-Baby Boom/fish-out-of-water/opposites-attract kind of thing.
Mostly it's a grim, violent and predictable tale of a young girl in unthinkable distress.

Ultimately, the film celebrates and memorializes the survival of something unthinkable, and a group of people for whom defiance meant, at heart, that they would push against the growing darkness and carry on.
A sweet reminder of the importance of family and community, human and canine alike.
It's just not particularly funny. That Segway, alas, only goes so far.
It's predictable but ultimately moving; a glimpse of a bond near-broken yet straining to become whole again.

That poor Vera Wang gown has to carry the movie, and that's too much to ask of any dress. Right now, the Wang is probably calling up the green gown from Atonement, asking how to get fixed up with a better script. I wish it luck.
A heartbreakingly sad yet remarkable film from director Sam Mendes.
You just can't quite enter the world of this film, not in the way that you might have if a more nuanced and less iconic actor had played the central role.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is that rare thing: a truly magical movie.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Frankel turns the camera toward the canines as frequently as possible, but too often we're stuck with Wilson and Aniston's bland characters. You wonder if it might have been better to let sleeping dogs lie.
The Reader, based on Bernhard Schlink's novel, is a tragedy told with such precise remoteness, you feel as if you're watching it from across the room.
Doubt, which on the page burns with stark simplicity, has gotten a little cluttered in the translation. But if you want to see remarkable screen acting, ignore the howling wind and watch these faces.
A convoluted tearjerker complete with murky camerawork and even murkier emotions.
Yes Man is a typical Carrey vehicle (schematically, it's a lot like Liar Liar), but it's better than most of them due to a top-notch supporting cast.

Were the World Mine gets by on sheer charm -- and on Gustafson's inventive direction, Kira Kelly's elegant cinematography and co-screenwriter Cory James Krueckeberg's whimsical production design, which works wonders on a limited budget.
Inland Empire is essentially a journey inside David Lynch's mind, sometimes burrowing very deep indeed. Nobody else could have made this film; nobody else should try.
All this visual caffeine is in service to a story that isn't worth telling, and that too frequently resorts to the cheap technique of putting an adorable little girl in peril, then cutting away.

There's really nothing terribly wrong with Definitely, Maybe, but there's nothing strikingly right about it, either; it's as good as it needs to be, and no more. It'll do in a Valentine's Day pinch, until something better comes along.
The party may well be ending for these gentlemen, but it was fun while it lasted.

Musicals ask us to take a happy leap of faith, to believe in a world in which people express their feelings by bursting into song. With Once, Carney has created that world within our own, and it weaves an irresistible spell.

There are some powerful moments (such as Elisabeth Shue, as Gracie's mother, giving a touching, unexpected speech about how she doesn't share her family's competitive spirit), and by its end Gracie earns its cheers.
Certainly more genuinely creepy than many recent thrillers, and the supporting cast is effective.
It's a very funny 90-minute movie, trapped in a 129-minute movie that has many, many dead spots and unfunny patches.
This film is less comedic and more sweeping than the first two, and Depp often seems to be strolling the borders of the film, commenting on it.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This Nancy is a throwback, but a charming one, and Roberts (Julia Roberts' niece) plays her with an irresistible sweetness.
An affecting character study, anchored by scraped-bare and often heartbreaking performances by Laura Linney and Gabriel Byrne.
Zoo, despite its elegance, teeters on a tightrope; by relying primarily on words from men who seem reluctant to talk much about what happened, it ends up having little to say.

We can count on farce, and on Veber, to ensure that everyone ends up where they should, and The Valet resolves itself most satisfyingly, in its tidy 85 minutes. It's a formulaic comedy that feels fresh -- and that's a rare accomplishment.

Movies, like poker, can result in some unexpected combinations. Who knew, for example, that the director of L.A. Confidential and the screenwriter of The Insider and Munich, working together, would add up to a losing hand?
Maguire has made Peter/Spidey all his own; the supporting characters are marvelous, but it's his brave, soulful work that pulls it all together.
Late in the movie, Cris shouts at a bad guy, 'I've seen every possible ending here. None of them are good for you.' It's as if he's talking to the audience, and alas, he's right.

[Director] Bier's careful touch and the skill of the cast make After the Wedding an emotional and often lovely film. It's mostly a series of two-person scenes, delicately filled in with character details.

Those of us charmed by the original Shrek and its ability to mix fairy-tale sweetness with some hilariously grown-up cleverness will leave disappointed. Much of this feels like a retread, a cash cow without enough ideas to justify its existence.
Though it's difficult to watch, the film is nonetheless inspiring: a portrait of strength and character, through unimaginable difficulty, responding not with hatred but with hope.
Though it's paced as a thriller, the film ultimately emerges as a haunting exploration of how grief can weigh on us, and the depths to which it can drive us.
[Director] Crialese ends his film on an exquisite note of fantasy: an indelible image of hope and good fortune. His vision is unique; his film, strange and lovely.
Interview slyly keeps you watching, wondering who will emerge from this long night's journey.
The cast makes the film a warm and agreeable experience.
Ultimately Goya's Ghosts left me wanting to watch Amadeus again, for the pleasure of a story well told.
With its zesty dancing, strong performances, goofball details and sweet message of acceptance for all, Hairspray might just be this summer's happiest hit.
For the most part, I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry plods along predictably, well-intentioned but only sporadically entertaining.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Blethyn, Chittenden and Wilson create a believable and ultimately endearing family; a trio of dreamers, big and small.
An odd but vivid and compelling mixture of big-movie showmanship and eccentric vision.
Posey's comedic performances have always had a nervous vulnerability to them; here, she strips away just enough of the comedy to break our hearts.
Continuing the increasingly darker, more adult trend of the series, the film version is swiftly paced, engrossing and often thrilling.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An unpredictable, enjoyable mob comedy.
Like some weddings, License to Wed is a long sit and a bland buffet.
Though the filmmaking is uneven, Evening redeems itself in its marvelous cast, which echoes the movies' themes by showcasing two real-life mother-daughter acting duos.
How good, and how much fun, is Ratatouille? So good that when it was over, all I wanted to do was watch it again.
[Director] Waititi's obviously a talent, but here he seems to be trying too hard to not try too hard; he's undermining the cleverness of the writing with the thudding hulk of its delivery.
This kind of heightened drama might not work in most movies, but it suits its larger-than-life subject: Dahan's La Vie is the movie equivalent of a torch song.
What will Wright and Pegg set their targets for next? I don't know, but I'll be watching.
Throughout the film, Hunt emerges as a likable man with a deep religious faith and an astonishing ability to reject anger and bitterness.
You'll be heartbroken in the course of the film's two hours.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Its essential trashiness too often takes over. Rather than wondering about Rachel/Ellis' dilemma, you find yourself pondering Verhoeven's consistency in setting up bedroom shots so that there's always a nipple in the frame.
Premonition works hard at wearing out its welcome, with numerous scenes that don't seem to add up and too many characters who feel underwritten.

Though the movie sometimes feels a bit cursory in telling its many stories, many of its points resonate strongly, in that hey-how-come-I-didn't-know-that way that the best muckraking journalism can do.
The writing isn't sharp enough for the film to work as comedy, nor are the characters real enough for the audience to connect emotionally.
It's an exploitation film fraught with faux-sincerity, and ultimately it's utterly ridiculous.

David Fincher's grim but mesmerizing Zodiac offers the puzzle-solving addictiveness of a detective story, the shivers of a thriller and the allure of a character study, all presented with a dash of newspaper drama.

The author's obsession with the number 23 becomes Walter's, and we're treated to a lot of examples of numbers that add up to 23, which means a lot of scenes in which people say things like, 'What's 14 plus 9? 23!' and look haunted.

I Think I Love My Wife has little to say and it doesn't have enough laughs to work as pure comedy. Rock the writer/director isn't doing Rock the actor any favors here, nor is he doing many for the audience.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mysterious little movie about a man following his dream, The Astronaut Farmer seems to be a visitor from some alternative universe, a place where logic and reason and recognizable human behavior have little reign.

Anthony Minghella's Breaking and Entering shimmers with good intentions and competency: Its blue/gray palette is elegant and unobtrusive; its cast is uniformly fine with occasional startling moments of brilliance.
It's a sad, haunting story -- but George Hickenlooper's Factory Girl does little to show us why we should care.
Norbit is as fleeting as a belch -- and even less funny.

Ultimately, the film doesn't entirely answer the massive 'why' at the center of this story -- that answer died on that day in 1978 -- but it's a haunting exploration of an event of unspeakable sadness, which still resonates decades later.
Spark? Romance? Wit? Nope, sorry.
... well-crafted but unremarkable ...
It's not a great movie, but for a Valentine's Day date this year, you could do a lot worse.
Never surprising but always agreeable, Tom Vaughan's Starter for 10 bops along like a hummable tune.
[Director] Nair and screenwriter Sooni Taraporevala bring the novel's velvety heart to the screen. The film glides smoothly over the years, touching down to give us the vignettes that make up a life.
Has a likable smartness to it; like a good Woody Allen film with a gay twist.
Reportedly, several endings were filmed; perhaps some of them make more sense than this one.
For the most part a taut, careful thriller that emphasizes suspense over blood and gore.

You may walk away from it still wondering why Nader persisted in running for president in 2004 after being repeatedly begged not to. But, whether or not you admire the decision, the film forces you to admire the determination with which Nader made it.
[Pearce maintains] our interest even as the film, in its final half hour, seems to take a few wrong turns on the highway.
What, I shudder to think, were the projects Hilary Swank turned down in favor of this one?
The Hoax doesn't tell its stories as well as Irving does, but it's an enjoyable immersion into a master storyteller's frantically made-up world.
It's harmless enough for young kids, but director Todd Holland seems to have little interest in making anything but a generic, instantly forgettable family-friendly feature.
There's little respite from the terrible history that this film retells just a determination (made stronger by the faces we see after the credits) to tell it, to be sure that history doesn't forget.
A silly spoof that's often unexpectedly sweet.

Gordon-Levitt finds something heartbreaking behind Chris' blankness; you can almost watch, on his face, memory quietly draining away. Quietly flavored with sad resignation, it's a performance that's remarkable for what isn't there.
Feather-light, Avenue Montaigne is lifted from mere pleasantness by its quirky character details.

Malkovich's performance, and the irresistible concept of an anonymous man dining out on a false identity, carries the film along giddily, and Cook wisely keeps Color Me Kubrick short and deliciously tart.
[A] competent if uninspired action thriller.

Shaye gives the film a message well worth hearing: Today's kids, constantly distracted by electronic devices, don't spend enough time connecting with each other and with their families. But this idea is buried among too many talky scenes with the adults.

Those who pass on The Dead Girl are missing something. Moncrieff has assembled a remarkable (and mostly female) cast, and there are moments in this film that are as powerful as anything currently in theaters.

In the Land of Women is a pretty enough place to visit (particularly the design-mag interiors of Ryan's character's home, all precisely coordinated to match her eyes), but as a movie it appears to have nothing to say.
Give Be Kind Rewind a little time and an open mind, and it just might grow on you. Its premise is absurd, but adorably so.

As Lemmons effortlessly makes her film both a colorful tour of the turbulent '60s and a delicately paced character study, the men emerge as two halves of a whole; often in disagreement, always brothers.
Greengrass somehow manages to keep the pace aerobically snappy for almost two hours, never letting it lag.
Romance and Cigarettes is a dark-red valentine to the way that pop music gets under our skin.
By its end, Juno, in its guilelessly chatty way, touches the heart -- and yes, I had tears in my eyes. This movie works, on its own terms.
A touching portrait of a man in the twilight of his life.
The Perfect Holiday, as many a holiday movie before it, meticulously goes through the motions, but never quite finds the magic of the season.

There's a genuine wonderment and breathless joy in Reilly's delivery that hints at what a fine stage actor he must have been, particularly when he describes going to a movie for the first time, or his thrill at first getting the lead in the school play.
On paper and on screen, Atonement is a story of rare beauty, both wrenching and wise.
The film feels long and slow, and the subject matter familiar. We never quite get caught up in it, despite the appealing cast; a thriller directed at a snail's pace simply isn't very thrilling.
Weitz's movie remains ultimately remote. It ends mid-adventure, so blatantly setting the stage for a sequel that the whole thing suddenly feels like a preamble.
