Essentially, it's 90 minutes spent in the company of some excruciatingly unpleasant personalities, and dimly lit ones at that.
The film is bracingly original; it's also mystifying, overlong and at times nearly incoherent. Floating at a distance from its audience, it creates its own smoky logic.
An irresistible blend of screwball comedy and Disney fairy-tale musical, Enchanted takes its enchanting premise and prances away with it, holding the audience happily captive.
The mood is darker and quieter than the Coens usually present, though some of the dialogue has a deadpan humor.
Mike Newell's handsome adaptation of Gabriel Garcia Marquez' novel looks lovely, but feels lifeless; the chemistry between the main characters just isn't there.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, Beowulf feels a lot like a video game blown up large: noise, action and funny walking intact.

War/Dance is the sort of documentary that's meant to appall us, to shake us out of our uninformed complacency. And yet there are moments in the film that may make an audience uncomfortable in ways the Fines may not have intended.
The talented Swank is slumming a bit here, but she could -- and has -- done worse.
The season's oddest and perhaps most effective war movie.
Meandering and often incomprehensible.
As kids' movies go, this is no Harry Potter, but it's an enjoyable enough adventure -- with just enough scariness.
Competent but ultimately disappointing.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film emerges as a devastating personal drama, a suspenseful horror story and a powerful statement about life under a repressive regime.
This movie feels very generic and very, very long; after it's over, you might need a little sunscreen for your brain.
The film, letting us read between the lines, creates a charming depiction of two people who become necessary to each other.
movie_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the strength of the cast (in particular O'Keefe, who's making her film debut here and shows tremendous promise), it's hard to muster much enthusiasm for Grace Is Gone.
There's not much that's surprising in How She Move, but watching how she moves is a pleasure.
Untraceable isn't unwatchable, but it's a pretty miserable experience, from a director who knows better.
Anker's film is an important one, shining a light on that red stain and how we saw it filtered through Hollywood's lens.
movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is an odd, disposable movie; it melts away as you leave the theater, leaving nothing but vague dissatisfaction behind.
Well, if you can figure out how this story ends, you've probably got better things to do than watch 27 Dresses.

Like the best of horror films, it gets under your skin not with gore or cheap jolts but with an unnerving, ever-building tension, and with images that remain with you long afterward, interrupting your own quiet dreams.

With the right audience He Was a Quiet Man might well play as black comedy. But Slater, disappearing into his role, brings a note of earnest desperation to his performance that's hard to laugh at, and hard to look away from.
The Savages isn't cheery holiday fare, ... and yet Jenkins makes her film unexpectedly uplifting, in a small-scale, real-life kind of way.
A film of rare imagination; a collage of unnerving images and great artistry.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In a season filled with depressing movies for adults, someone's finally thought to give equal time to the kids.
Watching it is like spending 90 minutes with a good friend: You'll revel in the pleasure of its company, and remember your time together with a smile.
Both important and engrossing, devastating yet inspiring.
When a filmmaker directs himself in a role that's hopelessly dull, is that professional suicide, or just kindness in not burdening some other actor with the part?
[A] chilly, masterful thriller.
A violent action movie with a heart and soul. Watching it is difficult; forgetting it is more so.
It's straightforward and nongimmicky (you don't have to wonder whodunit because we're told in the first few minutes), involves a minimum of blood and gore, and holds our interest nicely.
...there are plenty of funny bits, but the movie runs out of ideas long before its end
Them is more suspenseful than gory; there's little blood, but the tension gradually builds to a nail-biting level - an impressive feat, considering the movie is essentially one long chase.
The Treatment finds its agreeable pace. We've heard this particular story before, but it holds up to a skilled retelling.
Some beautiful shots give unexpected texture to the film, such as an underwater capture of a boat from below, with prisms of light surrounding it. And its final image is a quiet heartbreaker.
Delpy has a knack for finding just the right details; filming in her own hometown, she fills the movie with funny cross-cultural observances.
Like a sprawling afternoon spent reading Lawrence, Ferran's film is a welcome and often enthralling escape -- for Connie, and for us.
For those who still enjoy the formula, Rush Hour 3 will suit fine; but here's a vote for letting Lee and Carter dance into the sunset, having sung their last chorus.
Stardust suffers from uneven pacing and some cheesy-looking special effects. But the fine cast keeps things watchable.
Though the journey is a little bumpy, it's still a trip well worth taking, for all ages.
It's a simple, gentle tale that pulls its audience in almost imperceptibly; by its end, you just might be blinking away unexpected tears.
The movie has an immense charm that sneaks up on you. Ultimately, it's a delicate ode to love and honor -- and to writing and reading.
The Nanny Diaries plods along pointlessly to its flat conclusion.
A good -- and important -- story, not always well told.
Particularly for Radcliffe fans, it's an agreeable journey.
It's a worthy effort, even as it does fall short; a good meal but hardly a feast.
Bee Movie doesn't touch the bar raised so high by Pixar, but it creates a little buzz of its own.
All this sounds rather grim, and indeed it is -- but this backward Heaven Can Wait is also, thanks to [director] Dukic's inventive imagination, surprisingly involving and ultimately sweet.
Those who say they wouldn't mind watching Michael Caine and Jude Law recite the phone book may well have their patience tested by Sleuth.

Daniel Karslake's remarkable documentary boldly takes on a loaded topic -- Christianity and homosexuality -- and examines it both intellectually and emotionally; the result may well leave you blinking away a few tears.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful and interesting look at a little-told Katrina story.
A wistful and often lovely film.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Almost impossibly sweet, a tale of love and kindness that's funny without being snarky.
My Kid Could Paint That keeps us intrigued by the questions, long after its last shot of Marla.
Ira & Abby, in its breezy, low-key way, will make audiences happy -- something [director] Westfeldt already knows how to do.
The movie has an almost hypnotic quality; its spare and often beautiful shots seem to sear themselves into the camera's lens.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like the two opposing forces in the title, the book and the film compliment and balance each other; each is, in its way, a rich experience.
This is Gilroy's first film as director; I can't wait to see what he's got next.
Beautifully structured and performed.
...Things never rise above the competent chick-flick level.
The film effectively usurps the images left by Milos Forman's artful yet not entirely factually accurate Amadeus.

Schroeder's film, which combines interviews with many of the key figures in Vergès' career with grainy historical footage, lets its subject speak for itself but leaves little doubt of where the filmmaker stands.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bland but likable kids' movie.
It's all predictable stuff, but played with a nice lightness.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It has a genuine power: the ability of film to beam light onto dark days of history, making it impossible for us to look away, reminding us of what we should never forget.
A fine cast can't quite rise above a story without enough heart.
Celebrates community and family, and does so in such a warm-hearted way that its formulaic nature is easily forgiven.
In a movie full of surprises, the biggest is that Secret Ballot is a comedy, both gentle and biting.

An hour and a half of joyful solo performance.
It's the very best kind of documentary -- an irresistible story, creatively and elegantly told.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Serving Sara is such a miserable excuse for a movie that the constant ringing of a cellphone at its preview screening served only to improve it.
It's a hellish, numbing experience to watch, and it doesn't offer any insights that haven't been thoroughly debated in the media already, back in the Dahmer heyday of the mid-'90s.
It's the eyes of the children ... that stay with you after Ali Zaoua is over -- as well as the compassion that's evident in every frame.
movie_title: Ali Zaoua, prince de la rue (Ali Zoua: Prince of the Streets) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Those who enjoy experiment may be happy here -- director Steven Soderbergh, even at his most mystifying, is rarely dull, some of the performances are terrific, and the movie's likely to fuel some intriguing late-night debates. Watch your step, though.

Overall it's a promising debut, and a love letter to the droopily beautiful Gainsbourg.

Not much else in this third Austin Powers sequel is new or memorable.
At best, Cletis Tout might inspire a trip to the video store -- in search of a better movie experience.
A fresh cast, but a stale story.
The movie's chipper charms, and its steadfast determination to present an alternative to overly merchandised multiplex fare (there's nary a pop song or product placement here), ultimately win out.
The film presents a brief but intriguing biography of its subject.
Excels at building tension to an almost-unbearable point.
It's a big puffy French pastry of a movie: light, airy, silly, not especially memorable, but delicious while it lasts.
Pure formula, right down to Melanie's final choice, which will come as no surprise to anyone paying attention.
Chan's still a wonder, but The Tuxedo definitely doesn't fit.
Like its hero, the film seems unformed and rambling, more like a rough draft than a finished product.
It's beautifully done, but there's not much of a point to it.
While Simone has its strengths, perhaps we should have waited for version 2.0.
A film drenched in irresistible color and texture.
A tuneful, heartfelt tale of artistic struggle and eventual triumph.
movie_title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)

movie_review_blurb: An impressive debut ... rich with detail and cool-blue style.
A well-made and often lovely depiction of the mysteries of friendship.

Nettelbeck throws together a child who isn't cute and a woman who isn't lovable, and the result is one of the year's more heartwarming movies.

It's a smart-talking, slice-of-life comedy/drama that could just as easily be titled Our Bodies/Ourselves.
Within the clutter of accents and heavenly choirs -- Klaus Badelt's score is at times a bit much -- lurks a good story. And, in midsummer, that's often all we can ask for.
Not scary enough to work as a straight-up horror flick and nowhere near funny enough to be a passable spoof.
Miss this movie at your peril.
It's rare to find a film to which the adjective 'gentle' applies, but the word perfectly describes Pauline & Paulette.

A movie that both thrills the eye and, in its over-the-top way, touches the heart.

A shimmeringly lovely coming-of-age portrait, shot in artful, watery tones of blue, green and brown.

A gloriously colorful confection of music, theater and emotion.

The whole exercise feels predictable and programmed.
Not everything happens in order, not everything is explained, but it's all told with a haunting honesty.
Even half-baked, "Earnest" is still delicious.
Pacino, his creased face looking like it's been aged in a smokehouse, is wonderfully bleary as the increasingly confused Dormer.
It's a film at times so visually beautiful, thanks to master cinematographer Conrad L. Hall, that it takes your breath away.
A squeaky-clean, warmhearted movie parents can send kids to without worries.
Men in Black II, with its agreeably slipshod feel, is even slighter than the 1997 original, but as summer blockbusters go, it's shameless fun.

Some of the shots are so elegantly composed that they resemble classic oil paintings.
It's nothing more than a money maker for the filmmakers and a pointless star vehicle for Sandler.
Thirteen Conversations may occasionally frustrate -- but it brings rich, thoughtful rewards.
It takes us to a world we've never seen, to tell us a story both entirely foreign and completely familiar.
Is like The Graduate remade by David Lynch; it's no picnic to watch, but you can't look away.
Feels aimless for much of its running time, until late in the film when a tidal wave of plot arrives, leaving questions in its wake.
An intriguing near-miss.
If Dangerous Lives errs, it's in trying to do too much in 105 minutes.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

Bourne aspires only to be a fun popcorn movie -- and, for the most part, it is.
Not that there's nothing to enjoy about Divine Secrets, but it too frequently veers into screechy melodrama or artificially drawn-out conflict.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Although shot with little style, Skins is heartfelt and achingly real.
Secretary is a textbook example of a movie that's not for everybody: It's easier to respect it than to enjoy it.

Ultimately about fathers and sons -- but it's also about the pleasures of telling a good story, with retro charm to spare.

An intriguing misfire that nonetheless holds our interest, keeping us wondering about the movie that might have been.

Probably the most creative and noncommercial screenplay to be embraced by a Hollywood studio in years.

Bill the Butcher is a coiled monster with a guttural voice and a sharply thrown knife; Day-Lewis brings him to glittery, intense life.
Some day, Sandra Bullock and Hugh Grant will make a perfectly charming romantic comedy together. Until then, we have Two Weeks Notice, to remind us that bad things can happen to good ideas.
Peter Jackson, in the second installment of his Lord of the Rings trilogy, has confounded expectations and crafted a film that's both livelier and darker than the first one.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A Cinderella story so formulaic you'll be looking for a glass slipper.
There's a simplicity and heart to Antwone Fisher ... that's extremely appealing.
A good cop movie.
A collection of tepid chase scenes perked up, sadly, by moments of camel flatulence.
Gets bogged down by predictable supporting characters and some tasteless humor.

movie_review_blurb: A strange and fascinating experience; you feel like you've been given entry into a mysterious world, where no one else is permitted.

This "Madame Bovary" may not quite be Flaubert's, but it's lovely to look at all the same.

When a play is adapted for the screen, too often you can see the stitches.

Important but devastating viewing.

movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

An often strange yet always intriguing depiction, filtered through contemporary ideas of environmentalism and presenting its title character as a man of unshakable faith and almost unendurable burdens.
A pleasure, from the fascinating intricacies of Mumbai-style interlocking lunch containers to the quietly masterful performance of Khan.
Denis Villeneuve's moody, intriguing and, yes, occasionally silly psychological thriller.

"A Murder in the Park," with a whopper of a twist near the end, is often mesmerizing, even as its story remains unfinished. Justice, in this case, seems to remain elusive.

Mostly - as that title deserves - it's a funny, imaginative trip down a high-school rabbit hole, in which we're reminded that catastrophic disasters may come and go but what matters in high school is where you fit on the school's social ranking.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Did I actually see "King Arthur" the other night? Or was it all just a very loud dream?
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Snatched" is one of those movies that feels like a rough draft of itself.
This is really about the quiet life of a ghost, haunting a house where contentment once lived. Bring patience - and a fondness for Malick-ish stillness - and perhaps find reward.

Nothing terribly novel here, but director Brett Haley has assembled a strong cast and a generous spirit, and Elliott has a way of finding poetry in silent gaze, speaking his lines as if written on velvet.
Those fascinated by the art of animation will find much to ponder here - the hand-drawn brush strokes, the lush colors, the way just a few quickly sketched lines suddenly take vivid life.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is inspiring and funny and lovely, and you may find the words of one of the girls lingering: "If you come together with a group of powerful women, the impact will be immense."
It's a compelling argument, in a film that may well change a few minds - or at least inspire some heartfelt post-screening arguing.
This tuneful portrait of Chavela Vargas, "born singing" in 1919 Costa Rica, admiringly explores her impact on the world of Mexican music as an out lesbian ... a charismatic figure and a great artist.
Quiet revelations and fleeting poetry - a lottery ticket, we're reminded, is a piece of a dream - pleasingly ensue.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film filled with unexpected beauty: the "wishing lanterns" that giddy guests send up into the night sky; the vision of an exquisite, cloud-flecked dawn on the morning after; the frequent, steady close-ups of Hayek's eyes, as they slowly harden.
This is a two-hour movie that would probably have worked better at 90 minutes. But it's a quietly competent film and a good story ...
Weisz and the cinematography (by Mike Eley) are both better than they need to be; as for the rest, you've seen it before, but you might well enjoy another round.
Suffering Sappho! Patty Jenkins' "Wonder Woman" is that rarity: a superhero movie with a heart.
"Paris Can Wait" isn't exactly a feast, but it's a snack worth having.
Dead men may tell no tales, but bored audience members do. Open bar, anyone? Can we toast the end of this franchise? Please?
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Thinking is overrated," says Olly at one point; it's probably the best philosophy with which to approach this film.

Letts has some fine moments, but it's Winger who really brings the color to this movie, creating a woman filled with disappointment and passion and wit, taking a small-scale comedy of manners to a darker, richer place.
There isn't much of a script here.

Francesca Pedroni's documentary tells us little about the charismatic ballet star at its center, focusing instead on dance performance. But oh, those performances, captured at a series of historic Italian outdoor amphitheaters.
movie_title: Roberto Bolle: The Art of Dance (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I'll admit to having a pretty good time at "Kong: Skull Island," helped immensely by a very large bag of popcorn ...
"Get Out" will scare you, make you laugh and perhaps make you uncomfortable. It's supposed to.
Chastain, whose brittle Elizabeth never seems to exhale, let alone relax, reveals almost nothing of her character's heart - and yet keeps us fascinated by her.
"Office Christmas Party" is one of those movies that rounds up a terrific cast and then leaves them stranded with nothing to do - like, well, maybe some people at your office.
Not everything broken, this wise movie reminds us, can be mended.
"Nocturnal Animals" is, I think, a beautiful mess, but I might have to watch it again to be sure.
Too often it feels like a shallow copy of the movies it's imitating ... shot on exquisitely decorated locations that look more like soundstages than actual streets and homes.
"The Edge of Seventeen," in its R-rated way (booze and sex play supporting roles), is a sweetheart - just like Erwin.
That not every note or dance step is perfect isn't the point; it's that the actors find perfection - and magic - in the moment, in that flight.

Watch how Edgerton's Joel, a stoic man of few words, puts an arm around Mildred without seeming to think about it, naturally wanting her near; watch how Negga lets her performance speak through her expressive eyes, always looking for Richard.
So much of the pleasure of Denis Villeneuve's poignant science-fiction drama "Arrival" lies in watching Amy Adams figure things out.
It's less a story than a collection of moments, which leaves its viewer feeling moved and changed, as if you've spent time in someone else's dreams and woke up understanding who they are.
"Christine" is based on true events, and I suspect it's all the more powerful if you don't know what happens at the end. I did, but the film still gripped me.
You have, I promise, never seen a movie quite like Park Chan-wook's "The Handmaiden."
I gasped, more than once.
On this wintry landscape, with its endless plains and biting wind, it seems as if everyone - even the quietest - has a story, if you take the time to listen to it.

Even if you, like me, are a bit Pottered out and wish Rowling would devote herself instead to her marvelous Cormoran Strike detective-novel series (magic comes in many forms) - it's still a pleasure to revisit the author's world.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ruffalo turns in another take on his soulful smart guy; Brody's all loosey-goosey charm (watch how he plays a harmonica, with his eyes lazily sliding over it); Weisz make something poetic from her ditsy yet forthright character.
"Collateral Beauty," a movie so earnest it almost has Tom Cruise in it, misses its mark by a mile, stranding an impressive cast whom you'd think would have better things to do.
There are several ways you can watch "Elle," only one of which is mildly enjoyable.
Oyelowo's Seretse can both deliver a barnburner of a speech and put a gentle world of meaning into a quiet "Thank you, my love"; Pike's Ruth wears her wide-open heart on her face.
There's an interesting movie somewhere inside "A Cure For Wellness," screaming to get out.

Kids will enjoy the vivid colors and clever use of Lego shapes (the characters shake hands by interlocking their pieces), as well as the dialogue, which has the cheery, slapdash feel of having been written by extremely clever 12-year-olds.
A journey of discovery; a path of words and images, taking us into the lives of four African-American men and into the heart of the civil-rights movement.
It's one of the most emotionally charged documentaries you'll ever see (I'm tearing up at my desk just at the memory of it, so you can imagine how many tissues it took to actually watch it).
The camera keeps rolling, and you start pondering what to have for dinner. Maybe the actors are wondering the same thing.
"Gold" is one of those movies that sounds like much more fun than it actually is.

"Julieta" is filled with Almodóvar's usual attention to vivid color (a turquoise turtleneck worn by young Julieta seems to add notes to the film's moody musical score), and to the ways women talk to each other.
Except for a late Shyamalan-ish wink at the audience, "Split" is rarely fun or frightening.
The drama of Mike Mills' "20th Century Women" takes place in Annette Bening's masterful pauses.
The details of the story are often fascinating (you'll learn a lot about burger production), and the cast find plenty of moments to shine.

Older audiences braced for tragedy may be drawn to its imaginative visuals - the stories told by the monster are rendered in delicate, painterly animation - and to the achingly vulnerable, growing-up-too-fast boy at its center.
It's the kind of documentary that might serve as a perfect introduction to Lumet's work; when it's done, you want to watch all of these films immediately.
"Fences" wraps you and whirls you in a heady cyclone of words, ultimately dropping you gently on the ground, moved and changed and unexpectedly uplifted by the journey.
"Lion" has one of those plot lines that feels like a Hollywood screenplay - except it actually happened.
It's a well-meaning film, but you leave wishing for a "Groundhog Day"/"Mean Girls" double feature - and find, very quickly, that you don't remember anything about Sam at all.

Ultimately "Denial' works, thanks to its strong cast - particularly Spall, who gives Irving a slightly mad gleefulness, and Weisz, whose smart, tough Deborah chafes against the quiet acquiescence expected of her.
Just what you want a summer movie to be.
Mostly, the movie works for the reason that all the best rom-coms do: you fall in love, a little bit, with Kumail and Emily, and want them to stay together.
Movie musicals walk a tricky tightrope - all that singing can be magical, or it can just be silly - and "The Greatest Showman" teeters, all too often.
The film's an impressive accomplishment, on several levels.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Slowly, as if in a delicate tango, the two move toward each other, and "Call Me By Your Name" becomes the story of a connection, both sexual and emotional.
"Downsizing" runs out of steam long before it's over.
"Darkest Hour" is a straightforward, day-by-day depiction of world-changing events, told with meticulous simplicity.
You never know where "The Shape of Water" is going. But, like water, you let it engulf you and sweep you away.
It's just the same movie over and over, until the end of time and everybody dies, in which case "Pitch Perfect 45: A-Ca-Wait-Are-We-Dead?" might be a thing.
It's just a bad movie; a flat melodrama in which some lovely camerawork and a ferocious central performance from Winslet can't conceal the rote tiredness of it all.
It's most evocative as a memorable portrait of a woman, both in youth and late life, who always knew what she wanted - and who, in doing so, helped make the world a better place.
What a treat it is to see this great actor, after almost 40 years in movies, give a performance that feels both utterly unexpected and completely true.
In Leo, it presents a remarkable portrait of a complex woman struggling with forces beyond her control.
McDormand, carrying the movie on blue-denimed shoulders, is a wonder.
A cheerily uneven but enjoyable adaptation of Agatha Christie's blockbuster novel.

As an actor, Gerwig has shown an enchantingly light touch; she brings that to her work as director, as "Lady Bird" skims along happily, showing us moments both crucial and trivial in a teenage girl's life.
It's chilly in Oslo, and in this movie; the better to sneak up on you quietly, like an unexpected shiver.
"Molly's Game" could have been a terrific movie if Sorkin could have edited out 20-30 minutes; as it is, it's a good movie overstuffed.
The result is a stylish, inventive film that kept me intrigued, even as its story twisted so mightily I feared it might snap.
"The Post" tells of a great moment in journalism - and a great moment in one remarkable woman's life.
Thoroughbreds often feels like a very, very expensive B-movie, but it's all reasonably watchable, thanks to the elegant cinematography and Cooke's amusing way of playing teenage amorality.
Its message is of a young woman's empowerment, and of how love can save a family -- and if the special effects sometimes overwhelm that message, it rings through loud and clear by the end.
It's worth attending this party if only for Scott Thomas, who's never less than electric. Somebody needs to put Janet and her quivering energy at the center of a superhero movie; I'd watch.
The movie's focus on sexual violence against Lawrence's character ultimately feels repellent.
"A Fantastic Woman" becomes a delicate, moving study of grief, of quiet triumph over adversity, of adjusting to life's empty spaces - and learning to fill them with love.
"This will be a game night to remember," intones a character, early on in the film; this isn't true, as I've already forgotten most of this movie despite having taken notes.
"The Lodgers" is never particularly scary, or even logical, but it's always gorgeous to look at; you can see where it's going, but you might not mind watching it go there.
It's well-crafted and enjoyable. You'll laugh, more than once, but you might not remember why the next day.
Coogler is a young filmmaker - this is just his third feature, following "Fruitvale Station" and "Creed" (two fine and very different films) - but he marshals this world with confidence and flair.
Filmed with great respect and palpable love for its subject, "Big Sonia" is one of those documentaries that seems to bring its own light - just like the woman at its center.

Johnson and Dornan's performances are wooden and their chemistry nonexistent (particularly in the movie's more-of-the-same sex scenes), but think of it all as ultra-deadpan entertainment and it kind of works.
You watch "Winchester" thinking about the movie that might have been, and wishing that those ghosts would transport Mirren into that movie, immediately.
A gentle, sweet story, told with painterly artistry.
Paul Thomas Anderson's "Phantom Thread" casts a remarkable spell; it wraps around you, like a delicately scented cashmere shawl woven from music and color and astonishing faces.
It is, for much of its running time, undeniably entertaining.
What does it say about "A Bad Moms Christmas" that the funniest line in it is uttered by Kenny G?

The actors pitch their roles perfectly: Kidman's breathy calm; Farrell's charm, just hinting at something dark within it; Fanning's way of prettily arranging herself, showing off Alice's newfound power; Dunst's quiet melancholy.
None of us doubted that Cate Blanchett would make a kickass comic-book-movie villain, did we?

It's the kind of movie that you watch with two simultaneous emotions: fascination, and the desire to leave immediately. I'm glad, mostly, that I didn't give in to the second, but I'm still pondering exactly how Lanthimos pulled off the first.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You won't remember "Ingrid Goes West" for long after it's over, but as summer diversions go, you could do much worse.
Soderbergh keeps the action light and playful, and lets the cast members find their own silliness within it.
Walls' book tells her story crisply, without sentiment; Cretton's film, up to those final credits, does the interpreting for us, and the result is sometimes jarring.
Sheridan, the screenwriter behind "Sicario" and "Hell or High Water," writes dialogue that's lean yet rich, and gives the actors time to let their words hang in that cold air.
"Kidnap" has a tossed-together sameness to it, like a salad made up only of tired lettuce.
Bigelow has a way of making scripted drama feel like an utterly gripping newsreel.
Pattinson keeps you interested, even when the movie's tone and pace wobbles.
While it's still an enjoyable novelty to spend time during an action movie wondering where I could buy the hero's boots, it's no substitute for a good story.
"Restless Creature" isn't a mere celebration of a great artist; it's a moving portrait of what happens when that artist confronts the possibility of not being able to make that art any more.
A raunchy, good-hearted celebration of friendship; as funny as it needs to be, and possibly funnier.
You disappear inside of it and it changes you, as all great movies do.
The people who populate "Wish Upon" ... seem to have the brains God gave Diet Coke.
Along the way, some treasure is mined from the film's numerous speakers, all of whom seemed happily enamored with their work.

What shines through is the beauty of Guy Godfree's cinematography - the light has a lovely, soft stillness to it, like a painting - and a remarkable performance by Hawkins, whose impossibly wide smile seems to bring the sun.
Pugh, a young newcomer with just a tiny handful of film credits, gives a performance of rare ferocity.
That's the pleasure of the uneven but enjoyable "Trip" movies, of which this is the third installment: For better or worse, it's almost like being at that table.
It's all instantly forgettable. Except for the tulips - which, for the record, look stellar.
Watch this film for some turn-off-your-brain prettiness. Be prepared, however, to rethink all your kitchen choices afterward.
The film puts its viewers through a wringer and through a journey, right up to its final glimpse of a soldier, though long returned, finally beginning to come home.

You feel as if you've slipped inside of Moonee's enchanted world, while at the same time seeing the harsh reality of Halley's. That contrast is devastating, right up to a final sequence that's sure to break your heart in two.
The first half-hour in particular feels like there's no plot at all, just a highlights reel of Random Norwegian Crime Films In Which Everything Is Ominous and Everyone Looks Really Cold.
One of those films that's as good as it needs to be, but no better.
"Loving Vincent" is almost too beautiful for its own good; I found myself, too often, so dazzled by the form that I quite forgot about the content.
Robinson tells this very unusual love story with nostalgic charm, never hitting any of her notes too hard.

Never underestimate the power of a courtroom drama: the ringing questions, the preening lawyers, the dramatic pauses, the clicking of puzzle pieces fitting together, the ultimate belief in justice for all.
As with all of Wiseman's films, the whole is so very much greater than the sum of its parts.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the hands of lesser actors I shudder to think of what a slog "The Mountain Between Us" might be, with its endless catastrophes and near-deaths and melodramatic declarations.
This film - which is, we're told, "based on real events - mostly" - tells of how the elderly queen got her groove back, so to speak.
The pace is swift, and the '70s setting is rich: the throbbing soundtrack, the retro click of a telephone dial, the bright colors and pageantry of the match.
Evil is trending, indeed.
"Stronger," ultimately, leaves its audience feeling a little stronger; we fall with Jeff, and we stand with him.
"mother!," for this viewer, felt long and punishing; artful yet self-sabotaging, eventually crumbling. I never looked away - but I never want to see it again.
Even its title feels kind of off-brand, as if chosen for alliteration rather than art or sense.
A sweet, gentle story of two children connecting across time.

Bujalski doesn't give us enough in the way of story or characters, and "Computer Chess" eventually seems to just fade away; one of those movies, perhaps, that was more fun to make than it is to watch.
It tells, unquestionably, an important story that needs to be heard.

Burton, though his output lately has been bumpy (let's all agree to forget about "Dark Shadows," shall we?), is one of those rare filmmakers with a clear, distinctive style, and it's well suited to this material.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In the cast, only Isaac makes a vivid impression, in a swaggery, relaxed turn that seems to imply that he's in on the joke, or at least having a good time.
The filmmakers have described "Band of Robbers" as fan fiction, and that feels about right: They don't quite hit the mark, but it's fun to watch them trying.
Were the screenwriters hoping Hart would improvise the jokes as he went along? Or thinking that fond memories of "Miami Vice" would guide the audience through?

By the time the credits roll, nothing makes much sense, which is typical for this sort of horror-movie potboiler - the film's trio of screenwriters apparently couldn't find a decent ending between them.
The movie murmurs, when it - and others - should be shouting.
Lawrence is a joy, but the movie, sadly, isn't.
An engaging film.
You leave the film's soft-grained world reluctantly, as if taking off a warm coat when it's still a little chilly inside.

You've pretty much seen this movie before, but the chemistry between Fey and Poehler - famously pals off-screen - is, of course, a kick, particularly in throwaway scenes where they seem to be happily wandering off script.
All blood and ice, a stirring, unflinching retelling of Shakespeare's tale of a Scottish thane, his ambitious wife and a terrible deed that haunts them, leaving their hands forever stained.
Smoothly told, with the sweetly vulnerable Joplin letters adding an additional layer of pathos, it's a sad story that leaves us wondering what might have been.
Go watch "Young Frankenstein" again, rather than venturing out to this one on a stormy night.
Ronan, in every scene of the film, creates a reserved young woman who seems to mature before our eyes, quietly revealing Eilis' open, yearning heart.

Stay for the end credits, which include a tribute to the (sadly few) black ballerinas who came before Copeland; you suspect, watching footage of the little girls who eagerly wait after performances, that many more will follow in her graceful footsteps.
Only Vikander's performance elevates it above its pretty surface. Her Gerda tells us a story of a woman desperately in love with a man who's vanished, but whose eyes still gaze at her.
In the beautifully acted drama"45 Years," a marriage lives and dies; we watch its agonized struggle, like a butterfly impaled on a pin.
"Hail, Caesar!" isn't the great film you might like it to be, but it's very, very good fun.
Imagine being dead, and still having to wear a corset.
Kusama ratchets up the tension expertly; we, like Will, become increasingly uncomfortable, seeing evil omens everywhere.
Rockwell and Kendrick, both of whom can really sell this film's brand of laid-back quirk, keep things lively ...
McCarthy's trademark blend of chipper likability and treble-voiced rage just isn't quite enough to carry things through.
Vardalos has created a community of characters and players so likable, it seems almost mean to criticize - like picking on one's own annoying but beloved relatives.
If this film inspires viewers to rush out to find copies of Ephron's collected essays, or Heartburn, it'll be an especially fitting legacy.
Field, carrying the movie on her shoulders and handing it to us for our approval, makes us root for wistful Doris. Single-handedly, she makes the movie work.

At times, the film approaches gallows comedy ... perhaps a little too much so; at others, it's a tense, chilling look at a seemingly unbearable choice - refreshingly, without telling its viewers what to think.
I found myself admiring "The Bronze" ... But admiring isn't quite the same as liking. This film is a comedy wrapped in barbed wire; approach with caution.
Australian actress Adelaide Clemens shines in Justin Lerner's nicely paced indie drama/thriller.

You keep waiting for the film to come together, for Rick to emerge as a character rather than a cipher, for the women to seem less interchangeable - in short, for a point to it all. By its end, I was still waiting.
By the end, even though you know what's going to happen, you might feel like cheering. He's an unlikely eagle, but just for a moment, he flies.

Dalio, who based the film (his directing debut) on his own struggles with bipolar disorder, establishes a gentle, honest tone that never wavers - and demonstrates a knack for vivid imagery that makes him a filmmaker to watch.
A mostly agreeable but empty-headed mess. It's sort of the movie equivalent of Derek Zoolander himself.
You leave "Lady in the Van" entertained but troubled; it's an agreeably but oddly off-balance film, juggling and nearly dropping the star turn at its center.
You might find yourself weeping tears of relief when the credits finally roll.
It's like a pale, limp memory of the original film, its colors faded, its distinction wrung out in the wash.
Steen [is] in every scene of the film and crafts an intricate portrait of a woman teetering on the brink, but never toppling.

Though "Spotlight" is definitely a reporter-as-hero story (and, along the way, a bittersweet love letter to the kind of investigative journalism that's increasingly disappearing), the film doesn't let its characters off the hook.
It's always compelling; you feel grateful, watching, that this story is being told at all.
As the movie progresses, Will learns, in his low-key way, that life is full of unexpected twists, that love is hard to put away, and that people who share children can never fully leave each other.
"Cop Car" has two kids at its center, but don't mistake this taut, wicked little thriller for a children's film.
For better or for worse, we'll never again see television quite like that documented in the compelling "Best of Enemies" ...
What Segel does, from his opening minutes on screen to the movie's end, is craft a portrait of what feels like an utterly real person, not an actor's portrayal of one.
Streep's performance, like lightning, jolts everything.
Come back to the big city - and the big screen - anytime, Shaun.
"She's Funny That Way" is one of those movies that you want to like rather more than you actually do.
It works, more or less; the three central actors are all terrific, particularly Posey, who finds something vulnerable and touching in Rita. But you watch it thinking of other, better Allen movies ...

The Intense Tom Cruise Face - you know the expression I mean, where he looks like he's about to explode and/or start yelling, but doesn't - makes frequent appearances, as does the trademark arm-chopping Tom Cruise Run.
Smulders and Bean, with gentle and honest performances, sell it beautifully, and the tone is both warmhearted and realistic.
Fantasy is the currency in which adolescent movies deal (why else, in teen movies, would everyone's hair always be perfect?), and "Paper Towns" putters along agreeably enough.
Theoretically, this could have been a lot of fun, particular for those with fond memories of '80s video gamery.
It's a gentle examining of life near its end. And with McKellen at its center, his face as gloriously long and complex as a Sir Arthur Conan Doyle plot, it's also a master class in acting.
Forbes' sweetness of tone and wise casting makes "Infinitely Polar Bear" irresistible.
"A LEGO Brickumentary" is great fun, for AFOLs (Adult Fan of LEGO) or otherwise.

Writer/director Marielle Heller, in her captivating debut film "The Diary of a Teenage Girl," hits exactly the right tone for a complicated balancing act, and for a film that could very easily have gone wrong.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's ultimately a pretty sad story, and definitely not a flattering one.
If you've really been wanting to see endless shots of Owen Wilson running, sometimes while carrying a medium-sized child, the thriller "No Escape" might be just for you.
"Truth" is ... mesmerizing, entirely because of Blanchett; this is one of those movie-star performances in which every detail, every gesture feels right.
By its lyrical end, you recognize anew the beauty of small miracles - sunshine, a backyard, a new morning, an open door.
"Crimson Peak" is more creepy than scary (despite a couple of gruesomely violent deaths), but del Toro's imagination blooms in every frame.
Filmmakers Bryan Carberry and Clay Tweel, over the film's quick 84 minutes, find some humanity and pathos in the story, which eventually takes an unexpectedly heartwarming turn.

In the end credits, we see photos of the real Laurel and Stacie, in happier days, and you can see love glowing around them. Too bad that the movie, well-intentioned as it is, never quite catches that spark.
While it's clearly constructed with meticulous care, with the wire-walking scenes as breathtaking as CGI allows, it lacks a certain, well, je ne sais quoi.
Slight but charming, Nancy Meyers' "The Intern" almost goes terribly wrong in its first minutes, but quickly rights itself.
There are no rules, and no reason, in this world of death and revenge, and we see it through Kate's eyes: fascinated, repelled, ultimately haunted.

Short, tart, yet unexpectedly sweet, Paul Weitz's "Grandma" is a small-scale character study - and, because that character is played by the great Lily Tomlin, it's mesmerizing, right up until its final frame.
It's one of those movies that you don't exactly enjoy (so many guns, so many deaths), but you appreciate for its craft and tension, and for its cast's willingness to lose themselves in the darkness.
It's creepy, sure, but not very enjoyable, basement or no.
It's a beautifully acted tale of friendship, and about how sometimes, you just need to move forward - in a car, or otherwise.
Sometimes "Man in the Machine" feels like it needs a balancing voice. But it's nonetheless a fascinating film, as Gibney's always are.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Redford has said ... he had originally planned the film as a reunion for himself and Paul Newman. It's a poignant reminder, as in this film's best moments, that life passes by too quickly.
For a movie with extremely loud punk-rock music at its core, "Ten Thousand Saints" is a pleasantly low-key experience; it's a small-scale character drama about learning to live with loss.
It's a skillful, sweet-natured film with nice messages about believing in yourself and not giving up. But somehow, the magic got lost along the way.
There's a lot to recommend it, most notably a quavering, magnetic central performance by Emily Blunt.
Frot's performance, as a woman so caught up in the joy of music that she doesn't quite understand how bad she is, is particularly delightful, and often quite moving.

The film moves us swiftly from one breathtaking scene to another: a dramatic mudslide; a climb up a near-vertical rock face (by a bear who'd really rather take a nap); a fairy-tale-misty lagoon, where water blends seamlessly with sky.
Watch it not just with your eyes but with your heart.
A remarkable personal-is-political drama, set in barely postcolonial Senegal and France.
Despite its name, this is a fluffy cupcake of a movie - and sometimes, a cupcake is just what you want.
The movie gets lost in its focus on flash and speed, and forgets about the man - and the fine, quiet actor - at its center.

Franco grins diabolically throughout, and Roberts sounds a bit like a junior version of Sarah Jessica Parker's "Sex and the City" character ... otherwise, they're awfully bland, and it's hard to get too invested in their fate.
Maybe Woody Allen waited too long to make "Café Society"; it seems, weirdly, to be an uninspired remake of itself.

Shot in artful, quiet light (many of the frames look like elegant paintings), "The Innocents" is beautifully performed by its nearly all-female cast; each nun, even those unnamed, is given her own personality and story.
A charming, moving and over-too-soon portrait of a country, and of what it means to have a longer than expected life.

Stéphane Brizé's "The Measure of a Man" feels so real, you're almost startled when it's over - it seems as if this French drama about a middle-aged husband and father facing unemployment should just go on, as life tends to do.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Lights Out" is an effective, tidy little chiller; basically the same sneak-up-in-the-dark scare over and over. But hey, as we've learned through decades of horror movies, that stuff works.
Like so many small-screen-to-big-screen efforts, "Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie" isn't really a movie, just a stretched-out TV episode with a parade of cameos and boatloads of Champagne.
Ross lets the story take its time, but "Captain Fantastic" never feels slow. This family, right down to the smallest child, are detailed and interesting, with individually crafted personalities.
A vivid and warmhearted portrait of coming-of-age, differently.
Crucial to [the] fun: McKinnon, who steals the movie with her mad-scientist grin, eyes that gleam like a laser pointer and unexpected random weirdness.
The film is at its most compelling when we hear Lear's voice - or just watch him, seated on a theatrically lit but empty stage, thumbing through scrapbooks and smiling or wincing at memories.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A smart, wistful and very funny movie in which six friends weather difficult times but ultimately realize that they do, indeed, have each other's back, for always.

There really isn't much of a campaign to document - Barr, who says she doesn't like shaking hands and meeting people, mostly Skypes from her Hawaii home - and it's hard to tell exactly what to make of it all.
In this bleak West Texas landscape where everyone seems to be struggling, you find yourself rooting, inexplicably, for all of them against a clear villain: the faceless, predatory bank.
Just try to resist the charms of Mira Nair's "Queen of Katwe," a triumph-of-the-human-spirit movie that's ultimately, well, triumphant.
Feuerzeig lets us put together the puzzle pieces of Albert's story. The film's final five minutes - a punch to the heart - make it all clear.
The verdict, in a Bridget Jones-ian nutshell: not v. good, but v. enjoyable.
The searing documentary "Hooligan Sparrow" is a portrait of courage.
If Tom Hanks hadn't existed to play the title role, Eastwood would have had to invent him: This is one of those cases where movie-star persona and real-life legend blend perfectly.
The film is never less than interesting. But this story of a cipher, ultimately, is a cipher itself.
"Equity" is that rare thing: a Wall Street-set movie that focuses on women. (It's also directed and written by women, also still rare.)
"The Intervention" feels confident and accomplished: The cast immediately seems to bond as a group, with each playing a distinctive, recognizable character.
It's a sweet-natured, gentle film that might remind more than a few watchers of a special date in their own life, long ago.
A heartfelt drama that has a lot to say.
"Kubo" takes LAIKA's trademark stop-motion animation to a new level, using Japanese origami techniques to create a breathtaking fantasy world.
It is, as so many Streep movies seem to be these days, a wonderful performance in a movie that isn't quite as good as she is.
My mini-focus group - Fiona, Joe and Iris - was rapt.
"Indignation" is an elegant debut for longtime producer Schamus; a visit to the past, with both sunshine and darkness.
It's a movie that, by its serene final scene, changes its viewer. You leave happier, honored to have been, for two hours, part of this family.
It's a curious world that Toni is entering, and Hightower's quiet watchfulness takes it all in.

Blending archival footage, actor re-creation and special effects (sometimes all in the same shot), he creates a sense of specific place and time - and, in doing so, crafts a sort of cinematic ode to art.
There's a funny, offbeat movie lurking in the details here.
Smooth, smart entertainment, from its swirling music to its moody cinematography to its fine performances.
You root for Marnie, even when it's clear why Lori struggles with her, and you hear her persistent voice in your head for a while afterward - reminding you, perhaps, to give your own mother a call.
Ultimately, "Money Monster" is always watchable - but forgets to give us a compelling reason to watch.

Because so few movies focus on stories about women, it's incredibly frustrating to see this strong cast drifting away on a tide of soap bubbles - there's no movie here, just scene after scene of melodramatic cliché.
We watch Binoche's face, in eloquent, mesmerizing close-up; pain and grief engulf her expression like water flooding into a still pool. She has few words. She doesn't need them.
Give that kitty an Oscar, right now. And then send him to my doorstep.
An unintentionally hilarious example of biopic gone wrong.
It's predictable - throughout the film, I kept thinking that I'd seen it before - and a bit sentimental, yet thoroughly pleasant.
Carney has an uncanny way of telling a story through music. "Sing Street" reminds us of being young and lost in a song, realizing with a jolt that someone else had the same feelings we did.
A two-hour movie so forgettable that I'm not convinced it actually exists.
"Sky," despite its Hitchcockian beginning, is no thriller; instead, it's a character study of a woman seeking a second act, and of a landscape that gradually transforms from foreign to welcoming.
Too often, the dialogue is flat and sitcommy, and a monologue in the mirror by Presley just feels awkward. But there's much pleasure to be had in "Elvis & Nixon" from its two lead performances.
This stranger-in-a-strange-land mood piece has an appealingly serene pace.
"The Huntsman" is a flabby mess - yet another sequel with no reason to exist.
It's a film that effectively combines two distinct - and very different - pleasures.
Taymor's "Dream" is, in Bottom's words, a most rare vision. It flickers before us almost too quickly, passing by "swift as a shadow, short as any dream."
All of this is sporadically funny and cheerfully tasteless in its low-budget way, but it's also unevenly acted, a bit overlong and never quite as daring as it seems to want to be.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "The Angry Birds Movie" is unnecessary but cute, like a bonnet on a cat - and there are certainly worse recommendations than that.
A study in charisma, with two wildly different performances at its center.

Rylance, digitally rendered from motion-capture performance, finds a charming, gentle rapport with his young co-star, and his lilting wordplay (a television is a "telly telly bunkum box"; language is "a twitch-tickling problem") creates its own music.
An irresistible kaleidoscope of music and good fellowship ...
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you squint, you can see the thoughtful prestige drama that screenwriter John Logan and director Michael Grandage were trying to make, but it's lost in a thicket of stereotypes and metaphors.
It blooms with moments of astonishing beauty: a yellow frenzy of springtime trees; a still room where the light slants in the window like a reaching hand; a desolate landscape, impossibly green.

The blend of Johnson's laid-back hero-dudeness and Hart's whippet-fast comic timing should have been good fun. But somebody, alas, had an idea, though not a good one: Make Johnson the comedian and Hart the straight man.
For all the witty voices and great escapes (maybe one too many of the latter), "Finding Dory" is ultimately a character story, and DeGeneres' lovable, brave Dory swims right into our hearts.
It's a sweet, faintly screwball, faintly Shakespearean look at love, families and what happens when a well-made plan goes just a bit awry.
People keep suggesting to Lillian that she just move away and never come back, which seems like a fine idea. If only Blackway - and "Blackway" - would do the same.
Try to remember this movie, a few days after seeing it, and you'll find that - like magic - it's disappeared.
Oh, just try to resist this one.
Long before anyone in "Ma Ma" expires, the movie does.
The result is a fascinating portrait of a politician - a man who, it seems, doesn't feel that he exists unless someone's looking at him.
It's self-consciously mannered and merrily playful; a mixture that Austen herself might find just right.
"X-Men: Apocalypse" moves along tidily, but you watch thinking that all this used to be a lot more fun.
To paraphrase Lewis Carroll, the movie's running as fast as it can, but still remains in the same place.
Like a lot of weddings: sporadically fun, draggy in spots, ultimately forgettable.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Those with a high tolerance for good-natured "teen" raunch could do worse.
"Jackie" is mesmerizing; a familiar story told from an entirely different angle.
James Wan's haunted-house saga is well-crafted, convincingly acted, surprisingly restrained and scary as hell.
"The King's Speech" is old-fashioned filmmaking at its best: a good story, elegantly told, and a joy to watch.

Between them, Robert De Niro, Owen Wilson, Laura Dern, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand have 20 Academy Award nominations (six of them wins) in various categories. And yet none of them could think of anything better to do than appear in Little Fockers?
Bridges, that most natural of actors, gives an entirely different kind of performance: loose and playful, not worrying too much about whether we can understand him (often we can't, but never mind).
It's satire, but not quite funny enough; a love story, but not quite sincere enough.
Agreeable but disappointingly bland...
You watch it wanting to scurry off to read accounts of the real thing, rather than being caught up in the filmmaking.
There's not much to it, but you do sense, after watching it, that this filmmaker might someday make something very good, once she starts looking beyond her own immediate vicinity.
A movie that veers from ethereal beauty (its closing credit sequence, as a book of magic softly drowns in a dark sea, is a stunner) to mystifying cheesiness.
The Tourist is like a beautifully decorated shop window -- with no shop behind it.
A quiet, devastating, beautifully acted drama about the devastation of loss and the slow, muted, barely-there return of hope.

Wahlberg gives a deceptively low-key performance as the movie's still point, perfectly setting off the crackling fuse that is Bale's Dicky, a grinning strutter who knows he's screwed up but can't quite say goodbye to the limelight.
It's disconcerting but strangely effective -- you get a sense of different aspects of the man, coexisting as one.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While "Leaving" is a tragedy, it's also a celebration: of the way a fine actor can tell us a story, barely needing words.
"Love and Other Drugs" fits no convenient category, which I guess is a plus, but it leaves you not knowing what to think, so muddled is its mood.
A ballet movie so majestically lurid it almost creates its own genre; a backstage melodrama set in a dark hall of mirrors.

The real women of the Ford plant - seen briefly and tantalizing in footage played over the credits - surely could tell a more compelling story than this agreeable but overfamiliar effort; perhaps some documentarian, some day, will give them the chance.
"Blue Valentine" has a palpable air of claustrophobic danger; you constantly expect something terrible to be happening to these characters. And, indeed, something does.
There's something mesmerizing and special about "Somewhere," for those willing to wait and let the movie cast its spell.
Sometimes, when a movie emerges from a book, a crucial ingredient gets left out along the way. In the case of "Barney's Version," it's the wit.
It's yet another comedy that's trying too hard to sell something past its date.
The car chases and piled-on action eventually feel rote, as do Neeson's various badass stunts.
There's no unifying theme here, except that there's surely a short here for every taste.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Somebody on screen - you forget who all the adults are; they're not important - describes Bieber as "the Macaulay Culkin of music," which seems right, if a little sad.
For all but the most devoted animal watchers, the film may come across as slow and repetitive.
There's no real story here, just a series of gruesome yet weirdly casual deaths, taking place in what looks like the inside of a very big stomach.
A gentle, wistful tale of two people who briefly become a family, "The Illusionist" is both a tribute to the French filmmaker/comedian Jacques Tati and a final word from him.
This doesn't sound like a lot of fun to watch, but Weir - in his first movie since 2003's "Master and Commander" - makes it mesmerizing and occasionally lyrical.

A serious, thoughtful and often devastating drama about something rarely explored in the movies: the world of work as a place where we go to find out who we are, and what happens when somebody defined by his job loses it.
Much of Elizabeth Meriweather's dialogue is snappy, and "No Strings Attached" - though overlong - is mostly painless.
You'd expect Gondry's version of a superhero movie to be either brilliantly creative or spectacularly misguided, and it's neither; just sporadically funny but more often plodding.

You watch "Country Strong" wishing you were watching "Crazy Heart," and wondering whether Gwyneth Paltrow read the script all the way through, and wishing Bridges would turn up to show the folks how it's done.
Whenever "Guy and Madeline" becomes a musical, it soars.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "Casino Jack" is a portrait of a player - a man always dancing, always spinning.
"Client 9" is made with skill and intelligence, but I kept wanting to hear another story; one that I hadn't heard before.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Its screenplay is mostly second-rate soap opera and its direction plodding, with many scenes held, awkwardly, longer than they need to be.
Emerges as a quiet tribute to a usually ignored species, gently reminding us, in one keeper's words, that "Bees work together for the common good."

[It] will blow you away -- for its audacity; for James Franco's performance; for the way that, by the end, it leaves you feeling connected to the strangers sitting next to you, and happier to be part of humankind.
Though it's out of fashion in these days of Facebook and cellphone cameras, some stories might be better left unshared.
You again? Another dismissible chick flick that revolves around a wedding and wastes a handful of good actresses by making them behave in a way that no recognizable person would?
Though the talented Stone shows off some sharp comic timing, it's hard to accept this smart, gorgeous young woman as a school misfit yearning for popularity...
Behind the jangly car chases and the procedural action in The Town lurks a doomed, beautifully acted romance -- and a still-young filmmaker, already at the top of his game.
The movie works beautifully even if you know what's coming and knowing it makes the film's strangely beautiful early scenes even more poignant.
An R-rated romance that has its moments but is ultimately trying a little too hard (something Barrymore, with her trademark lightness, never does).
If you're not looking for anything particularly profound, it's entertaining, thanks to the zest of the cast and the stylish look of the film.
Clarkson lights up Ruba Nadda's stately drama Cairo Time like the moon on a summer night, making every moment luminous with quiet, resigned longing.

Richet's film is an engaging one, even if it often plays like a re-enacted, high-episodic documentary.
The film feels a little slow at times, but its characters always seem real, and the final scene is genuinely heartwarming...
In its murky light, the film is filled with details that seem utterly true...
Mao's Last Dancer is an appealing and, by its end, quite moving film.

Mesrine's life, however fascinating, had a certain repetitive quality to it (commit a crime, go to prison, escape, meet a girl, commit a crime, etc.), and the movie eventually starts to feel this way as well.
One of the many remarkable things about David Fincher's movie The Social Network is the constant realization, as you watch, that this movie should by all rights have been exceedingly dull.
This one's all about the horse -- and he's a winner.

Though the dialogue explores some interesting territory, the couple remain elusive and a little dull; we never learn anything about them beyond the subject at hand, so they seem to exist in an odd, screenwriting-exercise vacuum.
For those caught up in the "Potter" world -- and surely anyone who isn't dropped out of this franchise long ago -- "Deathly Hallows" is immensely satisfying.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For legendary documentarian Frederick Wiseman to follow La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet with a film set in a down-market Texas boxing gym seems unlikely -- until you see Boxing Gym, and how it and its subjects dance.
Some movies win you Oscars, and some have you playing second banana to an evil train -- and both have their place.
Morning Glory" is undeniably enjoyable as it bounces along in its messy way -- Michell, bless him, keeps the pace snappy -- but you just wish it were a little smarter.
The film lacks Frears' usual master touch; it often feels flat and self-conscious, in a way that the book never does.
"Due Date" is ultimately a long road trip to a predictable ending. Somebody wake up the real Downey and tell him we miss him.
Doug Liman's "Fair Game" is written as a drama and paced as a thriller, and it works just fine both ways.
One of those movies that disappears too quickly, leaving memories of better ones in its wake.

Epstein and Friedman didn't write the film as much as assemble it, using actual interview quotes and court transcripts. And while the loose structure takes some getting used to, it's ultimately effective and at times thrilling.

More than the other two, this is Rapace's movie; Michael Nyqvist's ever-rumpled Blomkvist has less to do, and their main scene together is just a tantalizing glimpse at the end; a brief, poignant reminder that we've come to the end of the road...
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the brief running time, audiences will likely lose interest before the film's speedy conclusion; turns out the most unexpected -- and entertaining -- thing about "Douchebag" is its title.
One of those movies that works better on a second viewing; it's a gentle, loosely structured tale of lost souls that'll wash away if you let it.
Tony Goldwyn's Conviction tells a great story that deserves a great movie, but settles for a mediocre one.

Discovered after the war, the film contains horrific images of starvation, poverty and humiliation, interspersed with surreal scenes of well-dressed Jews enjoying a restaurant dinner or an urban stroll.
Red is never quite the kick-in-the-pants that it should be.
Crowe and Banks actually make "The Next Three Days" work better than it deserves to; its pacing is off, and things don't really get moving until the final, electric half-hour or so.
May Nanny McPhee return again, very soon.
Woodman's black-and-white photographs, many of them self-portraits, convey a haunting sense of isolation; of something forever lost from the empty, almost decaying rooms in which she drapes herself.
An elegant fantasy, only slightly marred by rather too much science-fiction explanation.

Though there's plenty of skill on display here, "The Chameleon" is one of those films that feels out of whack, as if it focuses too much energy on the wrong story, leaving a more interesting one in the background.
"Horrible Bosses" isn't horrible at all -- it's easy, raunchy fun in the manner of the first "Hangover" movie (and far better than the second).

Ultimately, Rossi accomplishes something meaningful: capturing the sense of a workplace during a time of great transition, and, simply by showing us the day-to-day grunt work of finding a story, argues for the future of an institution.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: None of this makes much sense - except for the clear message that Europe is more fun if you're rich - but it doesn't really need to.
The movie has just enough funny lines and amusing casting choices to make it all go down pleasantly, and Hanks' sweetly brash charisma could fill an entire multiplex of movies and then some.
"Cracks" is a moody, often lurid tale of rivalry and repression.
Those fog-draped fjords provide a distractingly pretty backdrop to this tale of mysterious, massive creatures who roam the forest by night, searching for Christians on whom to munch.
The movie is an interesting reminder of how very, very high the Pixar wizards have set the bar. Sometimes they make masterpieces; sometimes, as in this case, they just make pretty good movies.
It keeps you off-balance, constantly assessing and reassessing.
Not much happens in "Late Autumn," and the film feels a little overlong. But it has moments of real magic...
This film's rewards are many, for those with the patience to simply let it float.

Coogan and Brydon, as they proved earlier in Winterbottom's brilliant "Tristram Shandy: A Cock and Bull Story," are a pair of pretty funny guys to spend time with; their riff on "We leave at daybreak!" is almost worth the ticket price.
Mike Mills' wistful, wonderful "Beginners" feels a lot like life - it'll make you laugh, it'll make you cry (well, me anyway) and, by its end, you'll feel as if you've learned something.

Abrams and executive producer Steven Spielberg are reprising a few of their own greatest hits, and creating the kind of Saturday-matinee adventure that kids of a bygone era would have raced to the neighborhood movie house to see.
Though Highmore and Roberts are appealing performers, Wiesen never gives us much reason to care about them.
By the end of "The Big Uneasy" the viewer is convinced that we weren't told the whole story back in 2005, and appalled by the retaliation faced by some who spoke out.
Exactly what it needs to be: artfully filmed, tautly paced, just sentimental enough.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Terri" sounds like a very sad film, and indeed it is; made more poignant by the quiet honesty of Wysocki's performance. But it's a wise film as well, populated by characters who seem utterly real.
If only it were 30 minutes or less.
Is the movie version of "The Help" better than the book? Yes, it is, primarily for one reason: The book doesn't have Viola Davis in it.
It's a film that brims with talent and ideas; it stays with you for a while after you watch it, like the way a shadow lingers on a now-quiet road.
Ultimately, "The Change-Up" offers a few laughs, and fewer surprises.
An odd blend of silly popcorn entertainment and sometimes startling poignancy.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In the vein of "Shaun of the Dead" but a lot less fun...

"Sarah's Key," based on the novel by Tatiana de Rosnay, struggles with a problem it never overcomes: How do you make viewers care about everyday problems when juxtaposed with the horror of the Holocaust?

Why does the villain Gargamel have a name that sounds like a sore-throat product? Why are there countless male Smurfs and only one female? (The mind boggles.) Why do they only know one song, and why is it so irritating? So many questions.
It's a tonic for those beaten down by years of bad rom-coms. Love conquers all -- and so, I suspect, will this movie. Just try to resist it.
Five credited screenwriters, and this is the best they can do?
Bears little resemblance to the book, and even less resemblance to a good movie.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's more to Ruffner's story than art, glorious as it is: "A Not So Still Life" is also an inspiring tale of rehabilitation and recovery.
movie_title: Ginny Ruffner: A Not So Still Life (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A lackluster, weirdly paced and ultimately dull story of a woman in crisis - played for laughs, except there aren't any.
"Pianomania" is at times engaging but ultimately frustrating; you keep thinking that there's a better documentary nearby, just behind another door.
Loosely structured as a sort of musical travelogue, with 23 song performances interwoven, it's as passionate as the singers it showcases, enveloping the viewer in the soulful music it celebrates.
It makes us happily remember the movies we thought Allen wasn't able to make anymore, even while the filmmaker reaches into the past to add one more great one to the list.
Everything and everyone looks very pretty, with even Kyle's disfigurement looking like it would make a cool T-shirt logo; nothing, and nobody, makes any sense.
The story's serviceable, if unexciting, with themes of child-parent love and the importance of peaceful interactions.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmaking is ... uneven, filled with charming picture-postcard scenes of smiling children and African sunshine that seem crafted for a different film than one with moments of horrific flashbacks.
You'll watch it to see a horror movie that has a sense of humor about itself. For "Scream" franchise fans, or for those who like their horror not too horrific, that's enough.
You wonder why this movie isn't a documentary, rather than a synthetic feature film with the heroine's arm digitally removed.
The whole thing plays like one of those supposedly hilarious ideas hatched on a late night - though generally, in the light of day, such ideas are quickly abandoned.
It's pretty faithful to the original, which is to say that there's not much there other than a wispy and frequently drunken fairy tale.

"Source Code" is perfectly enjoyable as a swiftly moving thriller, and Gyllenhaal is effective as a mystified fellow who eventually engages himself - and us - in putting the pieces of the puzzle together.
A comedy that's ultimately more touching than funny and a joy from beginning to end.
If history lessons could always be as compelling as Robert Redford's "The Conspirator," movie theaters might be full of them.
A stark, compelling crime drama, shot in lurid close-ups and leading inexorably toward a devastating end.
"The Lincoln Lawyer" moves through its paces as smoothly as Mickey strolls through a courtroom.
Some of us are "Jane Eyre" addicts, and the new movie version directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga gives us just the right fix.
