You sense that the characters, as much as we, are waiting for something to happen.
Just at the point of losing its audience, a nifty little film suddenly emerges.
A movie that has little reason to exist, other than as a showcase for Seyfried's uncannily beautiful face, framed prettily in red, and as the latest in a line of fairy tales on the big screen.
A pretty decent film in its own right, and a remarkably good one if you consider the filmmaker turns 22 this month.
"Potiche" is a pleasant, occasionally musical romp, and a welcome chance for Deneuve to carry a movie.
A quiet tale, told through a rarely moving camera and a playful, bewitching smile.
Well, it isn't the elephant's fault.
Beautifully filmed, "L'Amour Fou" is often quite moving as it documents the dismantling of a mutual life.
Phillips seems to be relying all too heavily on the idea that we just want to see the first movie again. (We can do that. At home. For a lot less money.)
Though this movie ends with a clear indication of more possibilities ahead, I'm more than ready to let Captain Jack Sparrow rest in rum-soaked peace.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing terribly surprising about this movie's dramatic arc, but it's nicely executed, and Ferrell's restrained, almost gentle performance is a revelation.
A grim little drama that seems to exist in order to give the talented Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Natalie Portman a chance to look extra-scruffy.
[It's] a female-centered ensemble comedy that's ultimately about the importance and power of friendship. And, yes, it's funny as hell.

Bonnaire beautifully captures her character's simmering intelligence and vague discontent; Kline, performing his entire role in French for the first time, again proves himself a master of the raised eyebrow.
None of this sounds as if it should work for a second as drama, so great credit goes to Foster and the cast for keeping the story small, quiet and often very moving.

[It] is wildly overaccessorized, giving virtually every character an elaborate subplot (sometimes more than one). This results in a long, lumpy middle section of the movie, before everything comes together for a sweetly romantic ending.
Not quite good enough to be thrilling, but never bad enough to be silly (except when it means to be), the Marvel comic Thor lumbers agreeably onto the screen to kick off the summer movie season.
Why did this movie leave such a rotten taste in my mouth? Because its story, based on Emily Giffin's popular novel, is a pretty repellent view of women's friendship.
He finds beauty; watching him, we find joy.
For its intended audience, it hits just the right note of drama mixed with cuteness.
An intermittently entertaining comedy/drama with a funny script and a fatal miscasting.

As a moviegoer, there are times when you want, say, "Jane Eyre," and then there are times when a movie about really large men who drive cars really fast is just the thing. "Fast Five" is that latter movie, and then some.
Though "First Class" has its share of well-honed action sequences, it shines in the same way the previous films did: through fine casting and carefully crafted characters.
Beautifully filmed in the harsh, dry landscape, "The Tree" is often mesmerizing...
Eat Pray Love is mostly a slog; never giving us a compelling reason why its heroine does what she does, or how she became quite so tiresomely self- absorbed.
It's a not-so-great movie about some great movies.
Two marvelous performances from two Irish actors turn Oliver Hirschbiegel's Five Minutes of Heaven into a tour de force.
The film, understandably, leaves you wanting more about the rest of the designer's life, but Coco Before Chanel is wisely focused on those years in which she became herself.
See this one with a crowd, and remember Black Dynamite's immortal words: "Doughnuts don't wear alligator shoes."
Some children, I think, will love this film, some will find it frightening, and some will be bored. Adults, likely, will experience it the same way.

While there are plenty of oddball touches, some mystifying (like the Yiddish-language prologue, set in a Polish shtetl and seeming to have little to do with what follows it; and the abrupt ending) -- we see in it some genuine fondness for the characters.

Imagine that you are listening in on the marriage-counseling sessions of the dullest couple you know. Multiply that by four, and you've got a pretty good approximation of the experience of watching Couples Retreat.
As with any such project, some of the films are better than others, but most of the entries in New York, I Love You are very good indeed.
Yes, you know exactly where this movie is going. But Barrymore and writer Shauna Cross give us plenty of reason to enjoy the journey, however familiar.

While it's fun for fashionholics just to watch a movie in which people say "It's a famine of beauty!" and "The jacket is the new coat," the film becomes more substantial as it narrows its focus to two people: an artist and a curator.

A strange yet riveting portrait of a marriage enduring a year spent making as little environmental impact as possible.
Much of Fame draws us in, through the irresistible appeal of young people bursting with energy.
The warm, elfin filmmaker makes a fine companion through this vivid story of a life well lived, reminding us at the end of how we create our own safe havens within our families.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an appealing central performance from Matt Damon, disguised in a mustache and complicated swoop of hair, The Informant! feels like a jumble of ideas rather than a concerted whole.
You may well cry -- I did -- at The Boys Are Back, but Hicks doesn't use hammers or harp strings; the emotion is honest and earned.
While there's plenty of action, much of it satisfyingly wet and muddy, the reason to watch this film is its splendid cast.

It's rich food for thought, though you wonder why little attention is given to the idea that perhaps some women relax their hair because it's easier to style that way, or that elaborate attention to hair is hardly exclusive to black women.
Amelia is a conventional, competent and often very pretty film; it's just never as interesting as the woman at its center.
Everyone recites their lines, awkwardly laying out exposition, speaking their clunky dialogue. None of this is supposed to matter, because we're presumably busy marveling at all the money on display.

Eastwood, tackling a sports movie very different from Million Dollar Baby, paces the action beautifully, right up to one white-knuckle moment late in the film (involving a plane) when you suddenly realized how invested in the story you've become.
Linklater keeps everything bouncing along, in sepia light and roar-of-the-greasepaint dust, giving us a little lesson in theater history along with an appealing coming-of-age tale.
Adrienne Shelly deserves better.

It's a timely tale of job loss and economic upheaval, at times hidden behind screwball-comedy dialogue. And it isn't perfect, but when it works -- which is most of the time -- it works like gangbusters.

Brothers has all the right ingredients -- it's made with care, and it works very well. But it rarely finds the raw intensity that the Danish original did; adding a little polish, in this case, took away a bit of the grit.
Captures the fleeting beauty of ballet in dozens of miniature portraits, each quietly soaring. This movie just goes up there and stays there, and it's magical.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, Everybody's Fine becomes a holiday movie of rare sweetness; one likely to inspire a few calls home to Mom or Dad.
Mortensen warms the film with his presence, creating a vivid portrait of a bereft man clinging to the one thing he has left.
Wes Anderson's utterly charming Fantastic Mr. Fox is that rarity: a children's movie for all.
No, Precious is not an easy sit, and isn't meant to be. But it's a film of remarkable strength and poignancy, filled with vivid performances that stay with you long after you've left the theater.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie gives the 'Twilight' fans exactly what they want but doesn't offer too much for the rest of us.
The movie belongs to Mulligan, whose Jenny looks like Audrey Hepburn when she puts her hair up and dons a black dress, and like every teenage girl who's had her heart broken when she cries.
The Men Who Stare at Goats doesn't stay with you long, but it's good fun while it lasts.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's a great movie to be made about the Chelsea Hotel; unfortunately, this isn't it.
Seyfried approaches her role with such honesty and vulnerability that she transforms the movie; you see, in her bottomless blue eyes, that she long ago accepted being the girl that nobody noticed.
Toss this one on the ever-growing pile of failed Hollywood romantic comedies, and wish Grant and Parker better luck next time.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Extract has its moments, but not enough of them. Think I'll go ahead and watch Office Space again.
This isn't exactly untraveled territory, but director Richard Loncraine makes this potentially familiar story fresh...
If you surrender to its pace, Tulpan can be intoxicating; it's like nothing else in theaters.
So Yong Kim has a real gift for putting children at ease before the camera, and her two very young actresses (who are not sisters off-screen) reward her with performances of heartbreaking realism.
This wonderfully gifted actress, whose beauty has sometimes distracted from her abilities, here makes Cheri something rare and haunting.
A riveting documentary from James D. Stern and Adam Del Deo.
Echoing the words of the great Porter song, Easy Virtue deliciously misbehaves.
For beauty, vision and the palpable sense of a veteran filmmaker still reveling in possibility, it's something to see.
Mann knows exactly how to pace this kind of movie, set to a veritable symphony of gunshots, and Public Enemies feels both wonderfully populated and beautifully controlled.
Mostly Year One moves along ploddingly, stepping frequently into bathroom humor and never quite funny enough to justify its high concept; when it's over, it quickly slips away.
A low-key comedy with its lead characters displaying an ambling, laid-back charm.
It ticks along as efficiently as a new clock. The performances are smooth, the car-crash effects remarkable, the pace never flagging.
A romantic comedy that bathes in clichés before rinsing off with sentimentality and spritzing itself with lame jokes. The result is, alas, a bit whiffy.
The Hangover should be a huge hit this summer for laugh-starved audiences; happily, it delivers.
It's a joy to watch, for any age.
Unfortunately, it's just not funny enough ...
The Proposal coasts along on likability, right up to its standard-issue ending; what it doesn't do is surprise us in any way.
It's a movie that feels assembled from the leftovers Allen found in his fridge.
You watch Management thinking of the comedy Aniston and Zahn could have made, and wishing you were watching that movie instead.
Humpday surprises us from beginning to end. It's a fresh take on the familiar topic of friendship -- and a wise one.

Dobroshi, a dark-browed beauty, has an arresting stillness - never smiling (except for one brief, unguarded moment with Sokol), never letting down her guard. It's a slice of a life nobody would want, and a portrait that's not easy to forget.
While The Answer Man has a meandering pace and ultimately goes precisely where you think it will, first-timer Hindman makes the journey pleasant among these literate and interesting folk.
Taking Woodstock has its pleasures; it's really a sweet-natured coming-of-age tale, with a famously groundbreaking rock concert lurking in the background.

Occasionally Art & Copy becomes an advertisement for advertising -- some of the talking heads are a little self-congratulatory -- but it offers plenty of food for thought. And makes it taste good, too.
The Marc Pease Experience is likable enough; it's just no Rushmore.
Sweet but instantly forgettable; a fantasy version of post-college life carefully structured to offend no one -- and intrigue no one.

Suspend your disbelief and you might find The Time Traveler's Wife a charming if mildly depressing fantasy. Or you might, as I did, travel elsewhere during it. Either way, at least it's a picturesque journey.
Hayao Miyazaki's magical Ponyo blends fantasy with just a drop of reality, and the result is irresistible.
Nora Ephron's Julie & Julia is one-half delightful and one-half disappointing; luckily, the delightful part stays with you while the rest fades away.
Political satire is a rare bird at the cinema, so fans of the genre should watch and savor Armando Iannucci's In the Loop -- a rapid-fire, profane celebration of the art (and artlessness) of spin.
Despite Bourgoin's dazzling presence, it's the hollow-eyed Luchini who quietly takes over the film.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Overlong and overwrought, Orphan stays faithful to every cliché of the genre.
A blandly raunchy star vehicle that does its stars few favors.
A fresh July breeze among recent (and mostly stale) romantic-comedy offerings.
As its 2- 1/2 hours came to a close, I was happy to be reminded that we aren't yet done with Hogwarts, and that there's much pleasure in a story slowly told.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Just the latest entry on a long list of movies that aren't even close to the great screwball comedy Bullock is capable of making. May it be the last.
Like an animatronic kitten that won't leave you alone, Scott Pilgrim vs. the World wins its audience over on adorable persistence.
Put away your period-movie expectations and you just might have a lot of fun. What makes this movie work is actually something very old-fashioned: movie-star chemistry.
What's remarkable is how Firth, with the smallest of gesture or nuance, lets us see this man's heartbreak without ever letting it burst through his carefully controlled surface.
Harmless, but dull.
It's not a terrible movie, but all the way through you feel as if you've already seen it.
Apparently it's OK to have numerous corpses in a PG-13 movie, as long as none of them have names.
By the end of Stern and Sundberg's portrait, you feel a great fondness for this tough cookie, who says she plans for her career to outlast George Burns' -- who was still working in his mid-90s.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like all Merchant/Ivory films, The City of Your Final Destination quietly shimmers.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You'd think Michael Douglas has played the charming cad on screen once too often, but damned if he doesn't pull it off once more in grand style.
Anyone walking into Eclipse without seeing the previous two movies would be genuinely perplexed; behavior that barely makes sense when you know the story becomes truly nutty without context.
Nicole Holofcener's lovely Please Give is a small, modest movie, full of the sort of characters we might know, or be.
This is a sequel that doesn't come close to justifying its existence.

All of this would be extremely irritating, and easy to dismiss as cynical manipulation of the moviegoing public -- except for the fact that even recycled Shrek is still pretty funny, and that kids will thoroughly enjoy it.
Just Wright has the right actress -- in the wrong movie.

It's a story well told, but Abramoff's voice is missing: Gibney interviewed him in prison but could not film him. You wonder what this sweet-talker might say for himself, looking back over that long, ugly money trail.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Robin Hood turns out to be, despite impressive battle scenes and countless horses, an actor's showcase.
A vivid and haunting portrait of an artist's long career, filled with snippets of dance film that make you want to see more...

That even grown-up viewers feel invested in the toys' ultimate destination is indicative of the affection held for this franchise; that a third movie in a sequence can still offer charm and delight is the cherry on the sundae.
Cyrus stays with you for a while after it's over; like an odd, unexpected party guest who nonetheless leaves an indelible impression.
Caine, that master of gentle sadness, lets us know Harry immediately as a good man trying to get by -- and trying to understand what seems like madness.

The movie is never less than compelling, particularly when Rapace is on screen, but director Daniel Alfredson can't quite find the delicate tension that Niels Arden Oplev ratcheted up so expertly in The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if the movie simmers unevenly for an hour and a half, and suddenly bursts into glorious flame.
You may never look at a bag of groceries in quite the same way again.
Take away the nudity and sleaze, and at its heart Middle Men is about billing. No wonder it needed all the jiggling.
The film, based on a true story, is an uneasy mix of generic spy thriller and tensions-at-home family drama, but it's definitely entertaining...
Of all the pitfalls potentially awaiting new freshmen at New York University, one I've never heard mentioned is the dance pimp.
There's plenty of suspense in The Wildest Dream, along with some breathtaking photography...
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, swift and scary as hell.
It comes alive through the memories of those who were there.
The only wit on display here is Roger Moore plummily intoning the phrase "butt-sniffing."
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Give these two a better script, and you just might have a comedy classic. Instead, we have here a tolerable near-miss; enough to keep the hunger pangs away until a real meal arrives.
Did he truly sell his soul, or was he just, as a family member says in the film, the wrong kind of hero? The film fascinates even as the man himself remains elusive.

The acting in this film is so good, across the board, that it doesn't feel like acting; we're simply watching a family going through some drama (and comedy) over a summer before its eldest child leaves for college.
It's a long movie (2.5 hours) but doesn't feel so, and is the rare would-be blockbuster that demands close attention and would surely reward rewatching.
The story, not to mention Cage's hair, is a little murky (can't a sorcerer conjure up a little shampoo?), but it doesn't matter: The fun here is in the action.

There's fascinating material here, but instead Kounen and screenwriter Chris Greenhalgh too often settle for giving us a conventional and even dull love triangle: self-absorbed career woman, ailing wife, passive man torn between the two of them.
Though the story occasionally seems a little too convenient to be true, it doesn't matter a whit, as the filmmaking is so skilled.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An intimate, small-scale story of a young woman's struggle to be independent of her scheming relations and to find equality in a very unequal marriage.
Face it: This is very, very cute stuff. There will be cooing in theaters, and a desire to reach out and scoop those kids off the screen.
Not much happens in this wisp of a movie (it's barely 75 minutes), and not much is necessary; it's all about finding a mood and letting it sneak up and envelop the watcher.
It's about as much fun as flying coach, and -- if you're seated next to Smith, anyway -- a lot less interesting.
A luridly effective thrill ride of a movie that leaves no old-dark-house stone unturned, including a host of rats, a series of flashbacks involving doomed children, and water, water everywhere.
Kids may well enjoy the adventures of The Lightning Thief on screen, but I think most readers will prefer the movie in their imaginations.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Acted beautifully by a cast you never want to take your eyes off, so as not to miss a tiny nuance.
With so many people hanging around, you'd think Marshall and screenwriter Katherine Fugate could scare up an interesting plotline or two, but no such luck.
Mostly, this movie is about two pretty actors moodily looking at each other with their pretty eyes -- and, for those seeking a little romance at the multiplex, that's often just enough.
In the film's dark final third, it's as if we've entered a waking nightmare, with stop-and-start rhythms as Mia takes one wrong step after another.

Kristen Bell, in the silly romantic comedy When in Rome, has the wry perkiness of a 20-something Sarah Jessica Parker, and you sit through the movie wondering what she might do with better material than this.
It's a new year, and a new romantic comedy, and a new opportunity to observe that Amy Adams' hair really is very pretty, and...sorry, I nodded off there for a minute.
It's minor Williams turned minor cinema, but there are nonetheless moments that resonate.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: First-time writer/director Cooper is a rare talent; he knows how to keep his story fine-boned and small, and to write a truly complex, troubled character who nonetheless enters our hearts.

There's nothing inherently wrong with a little fantasy; indeed, a lot of us like gazing at lavishly set tables and meticulously chosen throw pillows. But It's Complicated suffers from terminal niceness.
All of the actors do good work, but as is often the case in Almodóvar films, the women own the movie.
A few vivid performances emerge from the clamor.
There was no reason to make this book into a film -- and many reasons not to -- so you have to admire Peter Jackson for trying. Unfortunately, he's the wrong director for the job.
This ambitious, unique project, originally made for British television, is well worth the time investment to see the three-film marathon on a big screen.

Though it has a few moments where you can see Burton's imagination giving way to Disney convention, along with a bit of trademark Burton darkness, the pleasures of Alice are virtually always unexpected.
45365 doesn't quite satisfy, with many of its through lines feeling just a bit off.
Can I just go watch Date Night again? Please? Thanks.
There's a bit of everything in The Square, so much so that after a while it starts to feel generic.
Though never quite as stirring as March of the Penguins or Winged Migration, it quickly establishes its own gentle pace.
In his quiet house hung with portraits of those who have become ghosts, Michael finally learns to mourn, and we realize that storytelling is how a writer grieves.
A mixed bag, Death at a Funeral has moments of real wit -- and moments when you envy the corpse.

Date Night could have been another The Bounty Hunter -- a DOA movie-star romantic comedy mixed with implausible action/adventure. But instead it's the happiest of surprises: a genuinely sweet, funny movie.
What makes The Greatest work so well is that Feste clearly remembers what it's like to be 18 and to believe your one chance at joy has passed you by.

It's impossible not to be moved by the almost eerie film footage of the walls of the Barnes' original home with the art removed, revealing bare hooks and patches of unfaded paint: ghosts, doomed to wander.
Hot Tub Time Machine zooms right by, barely pausing on its way out (like, mercifully, the '80s hair it depicts), forgotten almost before it's over.

Butler...is stuck here playing kind of a jerk, so it's hard for him and Aniston to work up much chemistry, particularly as she's busy racing from the law in a pencil skirt and heels (easily the movie's most impressive stunt).
Told with a jolting, lurid energy, The Runaways feels oddly off-balance.
Told with a jolting, lurid energy, The Runaways feels oddly off-balance.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In Jacques Audiard's haunting prison drama A Prophet, we watch a young man transformed by life behind bars.

So many terrible things happen to the people in Allen Coulter's Remember Me that when the last awful twist comes -- something so resounding and meaningful that it instantly, horribly cheapens the rest of the movie -- you're almost numb to it.

The likable cast keep things watchable, particularly handsome Gross, who is surely destined for bigger things, and Ferrera, who's still as sweetly unaffected on-screen as she was back in Real Women Have Curves.
Downey still has plenty of moments of charm (nobody kicks a car aside as casually as this guy), and most of the action sequences are lively and fun.
This "Fright Night" is strictly for horror-movie fans; it's never clever enough to move above its essential silliness.
"The Housemaid" glitters coldly, with its marble surfaces and scheming eyes, as it builds to its dramatic, unexpected climax.
Yoav Potash's moving, vivid documentary "Crime After Crime" will make you both angry and tearful, sometimes at the same time.
We meet five of the team's members and several of their teachers; by its end, you'll be rooting for them all.
The camera work is handheld and jittery, reflecting Kate's often wobbly state of mind, and the character's decidedly nonglam wardrobe, minimal makeup and charm-free home feel honest and right.
It's really a three-character comedy/drama, with the best elements of both genres.
For Halloween-week fare you could do a lot worse, but "The Bay" fades quickly - like blood in the water.
Bursting with candy-bright colors and zoomy action, Pixar's "Wreck-It Ralph" should prove as entertaining as a sugar rush for its young target audience.
In Robert Zemeckis' "Flight," we watch a master actor play a character who's always acting.
Walken - and Zilberman - shows us how music can utterly transport us to another place.
There are moments when it works wonderfully, but too many where it feels overlong and ponderous.
It's confident storytelling, in which often the actors' faces, rather than dialogue, tell us what we need to know.
You feel its damp chill, enveloping the characters like a rough, thick cloak; if you screamed into this wind, nobody would hear you.
These girls - and Ruby - have traveled far, on a journey not yet finished; you sense, though, that they know their way home.
"Alex Cross" is a grim yet silly piece of work, even as serial-killer thrillers go.

It's a movie that seems to have a mild form of heatstroke: it's blurry, as if filmed long ago, and feverish, and the story wanders all over the place as if lost in a bayou. When it's over, you want to wipe your brow.
"Argo" is both an inspiring tale of risk and heroism, and a crackling piece of entertainment.
"Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel" is an intriguing portrait of a true original; you only wish the movie had half the color and verve of its subject.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Full of pauses and intense looks and vague standing around ...
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The photography is often beautiful (the blue glaciers sparkle in the sun like massive sapphires), but it's disturbing - and sure to convince any climate-change doubters.
"The Flat" is a compelling tale of history made personal, and of what happens when light is shone on something previously murky.
A workmanlike action thriller, competent but never particularly thrilling.
This isn't a great movie musical, but it's a good one, with a couple of truly transcendent performances.
It's not so much a movie as a loose collection of mostly funny conversations; and maybe, for the holidays, laughter is almost gift enough.
Some movies are all about chemistry, and "The Guilt Trip" has enough to fill a lab.
By all rights "Hyde Park on Hudson" should be a slyly funny treat. It is, in places - but it's also strangely flat, as if screenwriter Richard Nelson lost interest somewhere along the way.
The longest and dreariest 94 minutes I've spent on a movie this year.
The dots are there, but they don't connect.
"Playing for Keeps" plods along pretty much as you'd expect. Its small pleasures come from the relaxed cast.
You wish you could be seeing this performance live, as it's meant to be seen - but lacking that, "Barrymore" on the big screen provides its own thrills.
It's not exactly a perfect marriage, but Hopkins and Mirren create a funny, exasperated chemistry.
Director Eric Lartigau tells the story slowly, less interested in suspense than in character.
Alan Cumming has never been nominated for an Oscar, but director Travis Fine's powerful, fact-based movie could be the breakthrough role that makes it happen.
You don't merely watch Joe Wright's sumptuous "Anna Karenina," but you waltz with it, run with it, whirl with it.
A tragic love story, beautifully told.
"The Silver Linings Playbook" defies categorization: it's both comedy and drama, without fitting neatly into either genre.
It's a familiar story made fresh by actors who know how to make each breath matter.
For older kids or grown-ups who've dreamed of joining the circus, it's a wildly imaginative treat.
Older kids, horror-movie buffs and Burton fans will likely enjoy this oddly gentle tale of a boy and his dog.
Not quite pitch perfect, but it's irresistible.
This rags-to-riches-to-almost-rags-again queen has an endearing knack for looking on the bright side. You find yourself, by the end, wishing her well.
It's ... practically unbelievable, but you won't be able to look away.
As a respite from real-life politics (and a nostalgic reminder that there are indeed still places where people line up to vote on Election Day), it's a just-good-enough diversion.
It's ultimately not quite satisfying. It's a quick, tense trip, rather than a thrill ride.
It's refreshing to see a film that treats intimacy among an older couple as something real and meaningful (usually it's a punch line), and Streep and Jones bring honesty and warmth to their roles.
Most vivid in its early years, as we see the students bursting with energy and promise.
A pleasant if occasionally humdrum fairy tale, "The Odd Life of Timothy Green" lets us spend two hours in the company of some very nice people.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In the 98 minutes of "Pink Ribbons, Inc.," a wealth of information and images flit past, many intended to raise eyebrows if not ire.
We're left with the impression that though the mark may eventually be washed away, this man in a mask will never be truly clean.
"Farewell, My Queen" is worth a look simply for its look.
"The Watch" just feels like yet another generic Hollywood product; raunchier and dumber than it needs to be, never as funny as it wants to be.
If the people in it behaved in a logical way, then there wouldn't be a movie.
It's a fascinating story, even as Shea's film sometimes tells it in a slightly convoluted way.
You feel yourself slowing down and relaxing as you watch; there's nothing rushed or crowded about this film, just a quiet story carefully told.
There are moments in this movie that are mind-bendingly funny, and that fill the viewer with the thrill of discovering great new talent.
It's filled with clever detail, both old-school and state-of-the-art.

The performances through "Sparkle" are strong - Sparks has a gentle, sweet little-sister quality that draws you to her, nicely balanced by Ejogo's smoldering fire - and the colorful 1960s costumes (by Ruth E. Carter) and elaborate hairstyles are a kick.
A low-key, homemade pleasure; a quiet, appealing film about a late chapter in life.
Here's how to make sure your novel arrives on screen with its soul intact: adapt and direct it yourself.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Though this is a shadowy, violent film, Johnson wisely inserts just enough humor to create shades of gray rather than blackness.
Lynskey lets us see, from deep within Amy's fog, an instinctual desire to please, and a sense of innocent wonderment at how she could possibly have gotten into such a mess.
This portrait of 1950s America is like none you've ever seen, and it's unsettling - but the minute it was over, I wanted to watch it again.
Radnor ... finds both wit and truth in his characters as they face, in their different ways, growing up.
"Arbitrage" is a fine showcase for the silky talents of Richard Gere, who's so smooth here you could spread him on toast.
[Delpy] and Rock, in the midst of free-flying French chaos, find a sweet chemistry together ...
You wish it were better than it is, simply because nobody ever makes literary thrillers these days.
It feels like a movie you've seen already - and it was better the first time around.
Though the story spirals a little out of control in the film's final scenes, "The Awakening" offers the low-key pleasures of an old-fashioned thriller and a lovely central performance.
"Cosmopolis," because of its allegiance to the book's mannered, offbeat language, feels like it never wakes up.
A different kind of romantic comedy: one that starts at the end and tries to make sense of itself.
Visually, it's often remarkable - even if, like those multicolored sands, it too quickly slips away.
You watch "Searching for Sugar Man" at first fascinated by the mystery - what happened to Rodriguez? Where did he go? Then you become infuriated by its revelations of financial injustice.
Silly stuff, but for an end-of-summer matinee you could do a whole lot worse - and, by this point of the summer, probably have.
Though it's wonderfully acted, the film stacks the deck so badly that it fails as drama.
A satisfying and often breathtaking tale of good and evil.
While there's little doubt about where "Promised Land" is going (you don't think a Gus Van Sant movie is going to side with a corporation, do you?), it's a pleasure to watch it go there.
While it's audacious on the part of the filmmakers (and of Leo) to keep Francine at arm's length from us, it makes the film a frustrating experience.
A frequently off-putting film about two teenage assassins.
"What Maisie Knew" packs a surprising emotional punch, one that stays with you for a while when the movie's over.
"Now You See Me," despite some compelling moments, is one of those movies you watch while thinking about other movies that you're not watching.
Baumbach ... makes the film a celebration of Gerwig's coltish, goofball appeal.
A gloriously gilded wonderland - the stuff of dreams, on view for everyone.
Let's just cut to another car chase, OK? That's what this franchise knows how to do, and if that's the kind of popcorn fun you're looking for, "F&F 6" has the goods.

Part of the movie's pleasure is how comfortable the "storytellers" are with their director; you get a sense of a complicated but tight-knit family, going along with Sarah's project because they love her.
The story's simple enough to appeal to young kids (the 8-year-old with me pronounced the movie "awesome"), but adults will enjoy the beautiful animation, whether 3D or 2D.
It's fiction about life that becomes fiction that might be life - and the viewer happily dives in.

Written and played with a little more subtlety, Henry and his contradictions could have been fascinating; as it is, "At Any Price" keeps us at a distance, gazing at characters who never quite come to life.
Where this "Gatsby" fails, it at least does so with imaginative and verve; where it succeeds, it finds poetry.

"Deceptive Practice" lets us peer up close at what he's doing - camera tight on the cards, Jay's sleeves pushed up - and we still don't know how he does it; for lack of a better phrase, it's like magic.
movie_title: Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "No Place on Earth" is at its most moving when showing us, in close-up, the still-haunted faces of the cave dwellers, many of whom tell their stories to director Janet Tobias' camera.
"Iron Man 3" is definitely a big perk-up from the almost-but-not-quite-listless "Iron Man 2"; maybe hanging out with the Avengers was a tonic for him.
It's often mesmerizing, primarily for Shannon's performance as a man who's a master of compartmentalizing ...
Levy's so busy showing us the riderless cars and cheery Google bikes, he forgets to have his movie make any sense.
[It] is thoughtfully crafted and occasionally breathtaking; what it isn't, unfortunately, is much fun.
Though "Before Midnight" is often uncomfortable to watch, it's never less than mesmerizing - and ultimately, a joy to walk with this prickly but fascinating couple again.
Ultimately, "Turbo" nicely lives up to its diminutive hero's credo of, "No dream is too big, and no dreamer too small" - a pleasant thought, for people of all sizes.

Imhoof's film is remarkable in its close-up photography. The bees loom large, like creatures from some mutant planet; dangle together in a delicate chain; and fill the air, floating like unusually vivid dust specks.
Feels familiar, but in a good way, like a comfortably rumpled beach house you're happy to return to year after year.
Writer/director Peter Strickland intriguingly weaves into the story a movie-within-a-movie that we barely see, but we hear.
The gentle story of a marriage, and of how music can help make a broken heart whole again.
It's a pleasure to see a vampire movie that aspires to something artful, and that explores the misery that comes with living - forever - on blood, and in the shadows.
It's not quite funny enough to be a comedy, nor quite exciting enough to be an action film - until the last 20 minutes or so, when it's a little too late.

The movie, made by three former teenage fans of the show, is an odd mixture of admiration and repulsion; even his friends and former producers, interviewed for the camera, seemed mixed in their feelings for him.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The veil is lifted on this secret movement, one that everyone else thought was just about dancing and doing coke.
There's a discussion to be had about why this is the only major movie this summer with two women in the lead roles - but it's hard to have a serious discussion when you're laughing.
Though Whedon's trimmed the play down, to make it an appropriate movie length, he's kept the dialogue intact, and the pleasure the cast gets in saying the lines is palpable.
Ultimately, though the pace is snappy, the film feels a little empty; these teens seem too soulless even for satire.
The whole thing is much more fun than you'd imagine watching people drink would be, and by the end, you're surprisingly invested in which of the guys, if any, will pass the final test.
Not every film can be a "Finding Nemo" or a "Ratatouille."
Engagingly looks at the new age of the craft cocktail, and the masters who mix them.
It's a mess, and not in a good way.
The performances and music are a pleasure, and Chase's affection for the period is palpable.
It's a documentary that's filled with beautiful images but nonetheless feels unfocused.

"Rust and Bone" seems to wander unexpectedly into its heart; it feels organic in its casual unfolding, like life itself.

This is movie magic -- history coming to life, before our eyes.
For much of its running time it somehow fails to capture what makes the book work so well.
[It] isn't easy viewing - but just try to look away.
A pleasant ramble through little-known cinematic territory.
movie_title: Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film (2012)

Very little in this movie makes any sense, even as glossy Valentine's Day fare.

[A] thoughtful and often powerful film ...

A story of obsession, of the permanence of loss, of how deeds of the past haunt us, closing over our heads like water. It leaves you shivering, yet thrilled; waiting anxiously for this talented new filmmaker's next work.
"The Host" is like a confused guest who stays too long - but at least it's good for a few laughs.
A moving portrait of people doing their jobs under very difficult circumstances - and, in virtually every moment we see, doing them with efficiency, wisdom and compassion.

An often pleasant, faintly comedic drama that too often struggles to find its tone.
Nguyen, astonishingly, manages to wring something vaguely like a happy ending from this tragic story.
A real-life horror story, made no less shocking by the familiarity of its early scenes.
[It] seems to be unfolding somewhere else; somewhere where it makes sense that everyone seems to be sleepwalking.
You watch it thinking that it should be smarter and funnier, but you have a pretty good time anyway.
"Oz the Great and Powerful" isn't a masterpiece for the ages, but an agreeable family film that pleasantly reminds us of something greater - of a land that we heard of, once in a lullaby.

It's stuck in a big-budget-movie middle ground - not quite thrilling enough to be an action movie, not quite funny enough for a comedy - and, once you've pondered the impressive size of the beanstalk, there's not much else there.

One of those documentaries that you watch both fascinated and repulsed - and one of those films that you sense just might be instrumental in helping to change an utterly unacceptable status quo.

Ultimately "Shame" emerges as a sex tragedy, and a story without an end; it stays with you, like the film's frequent cold rain, hard to watch and harder to forget.
Like the stroke of midnight, "New Year's Eve" disappears almost instantly, leaving little behind but limp streamers and the sense that, surely, there was a better party going on somewhere else.
You leave "Cooking in Progress" with respect for a man who followed his vision, and with fascination at the idea of food as artistic expression.
It's enjoyable as a character study, of a character most of us wouldn't want to meet.
The end result is a film that's un- deniably moving in its depiction of life under siege, in which horrific violence coexists with everyday emotions.

[Williams] floats through the movie, perfectly capturing Monroe's way of rhythmically whispering through a song, looking softly frightened when uncertain, and not strolling so much as delicately oozing across the floor.
A sweet yet occasionally heavy-handed comedy about class relations in 1962 Paris...

movie_review_blurb: A stylish if familiar tale of a man hopelessly entangled in his past.

Suffers from a case of Haven't-I-Seen-This-Movie-Before-itis.
It's an uneven movie, but a heartfelt and honest one.

movie_review_blurb: It might feel almost too quiet, if not for Knightley's manic, borderline-over-the-top depiction of mental illness; she's unafraid to deploy an almost comic, grimacing underbite and a desperate, unfettered sense of panic.

Messy but masterful; a sprawling portrait of what it means to be a bright young woman who's realizing that the world isn't the warm bath of acceptance that her privileged life would indicate.
This film needs to be watched by teenage girls, for whom it may well serve as both a wake-up call and a course called Women's Images in Media 101.
Pain plus time, this film reminds us, can result in poetry.
It's a genuinely moving and often lovely piece of work - beautifully acted and, ultimately, earning its tears.

An informative and inspiring documentary about a man's life and work.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Though an only decent adaptation, The Beguiled is deftly directed by Coppola, giving room for the cast to shine in their performances.

Though Sharknado 3: Oh Hell No! delivers bigger stakes, more sharks, more gore, more cameos, and more interaction with its viewers, the third installment to the series is a serious departure from what was appealing about the original.
Rough Night offers an entertaining genderswap on the bromantic comedy, which especially works thanks to its Broad City brand of humor.
